questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain for 3 days. The pain is retrosternal, 8 out of 10 in intensity, increases with respiration, and decreases while sitting upright and leaning forward. He has nausea and myalgia. He has not had fever or a cough. He has asthma and was treated for bronchitis 6 months ago with azithromycin. His mother has hypertension. He uses an over-the-counter inhaler. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Breath sounds are normal. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched grating sound between S1 and S2. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dl


Glucose
93 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


Troponin I
0.23 ng/mL


An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations in all leads. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of acute myocardial infarction (MI) that leads to mitral regurgitation with subsequent hypotension and pulmonary edema. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with ST elevations in anatomically contiguous leads on ECG.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary infarction is most commonly caused by pulmonary embolism (PE), which can also present with chest pain and nonspecific ST elevation. However, other common features of PE would be expected, including dyspnea, tachypnea, cough, hypotension, or signs of right ventricular pressure overload on ECG (e.g., right axis deviation). The absence of these symptoms in this case, as well as the presence of a friction rub on auscultation, make pulmonary embolism and therefore pulmonary infarction unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Mediastinitis may occur as a result of esophageal disorders (e.g., Boerhaave syndrome). Patients with Boerhaave syndrome often present with a history of explosive vomiting and symptoms such as retrosternal pain and mediastinal emphysema (Mackler triad). The retrosternal pain seen in this patient makes Boerhaave syndrome an important differential diagnosis. However, in this case, the patient's history, auscultatory and ECG findings are suggestive of a different disease.

D) CORRECT:

Pericarditis is a common cause of cardiac tamponade; it may occur in cases in which the pericardium becomes scarred and less elastic, while increased amounts of inflammatory fluids are secreted into the pericardial space. Cardiac tamponade can lead to hemodynamic compromise; therefore, treatment with pericardiocentesis is indicated.

Another complication of acute pericarditis is chronic, constrictive pericarditis, which may develop after several years.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventricular aneurysm is a late (> 3 weeks) complication of myocardial infarction (MI) that presents with persistent ST elevations and T wave inversions on ECG and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and thromboembolisms. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with more specific findings on ECG. Considering the timing and that MI is unlikely, ventricular aneurysm can be ruled out.
questions.hint: The patient's 3-day history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up, in conjunction with a friction rub on cardiac auscultation, nausea, and myalgia, is suggestive of acute pericarditis. The ECG finding of ST elevations in all leads with a mild increase in troponin I further support the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of shortness of breath and swollen extremities for 2 weeks. He has had excessive night sweats and a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the last 8 weeks. He had an anterior myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He immigrated from Indonesia 4 months ago. He works in a shipyard. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. Current medications include insulin, aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol, and ramipril. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 46.7 kg (103 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/95 mm Hg. Examination shows generalized pitting edema. There is jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, and a paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration. Chest x-ray shows bilateral pleural effusion, patchy infiltrates in the right middle lobe, and pericardial thickening and calcifications. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.5 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Glucose
negative


 Protein
1+


Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uremia is the excess of urea nitrogen in the blood, typically caused by chronic kidney disease. Severe uremia may affect the heart, causing fibrinous pericarditis. This patient has pericarditis; however, this patient's urea nitrogen is only marginally elevated, making uremia as the explanation for this patient's symptoms unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis is inflammation of the heart muscle most commonly caused by viruses. Acute viral myocarditis is typically a sequela of a viral upper respiratory infection and may lead to concurrent inflammation of the pericardium. Although this patient's shortness of breath and fever may point to myocarditis, this patient does not have any chest pain or cardiac arrhythmias, which are typical findings in myocarditis. Additionally, pericardial thickening and calcifications suggest chronic pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease affecting the metabolism of glucose. Complications of diabetes mellitus include diabetic nephropathy, which may present with peripheral and pulmonary edema in cases of nephrotic-range proteinuria. However, the laboratory values only suggest mild kidney damage, and diabetes mellitus would not explain the findings of jugular venous distention and the positive Kussmaul sign.

D) CORRECT:

Shortness of breath, night sweats, weight loss, low-grade fever, and patchy pulmonary infiltrations in a patient who has recently migrated from an endemic region strongly suggest tuberculosis (TB). TB can affect any organ, including the heart, and is the most common cause of constrictive pericarditis in countries with a high TB prevalence.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is characterized by the build-up of abnormal protein fibers in various tissues. In the heart, amyloidosis causes restrictive cardiomyopathy, manifesting with signs of diastolic heart failure. Although the findings of dyspnea, jugular venous distention, and hepatomegaly may suggest heart failure, amyloidosis would not explain the low-grade fever, night sweats, and pericardial thickening seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease that results from exposure to asbestos fibers. Although this patient's occupation as a shipyard worker may suggest possible exposure to asbestos fibers, the absence of cough and interstitial fibrosis on imaging makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, asbestosis does not cause constrictive pericarditis.

G) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome, also known as Dressler's syndrome, is an immune-mediated inflammation of the pericardium that usually occurs 1–8 weeks after myocardial infarction. Although this patient presents with pericarditis, the occurrence of it 3 years after this patient's myocardial infarction would be very unusual. While this diabetic patient may have recently experienced a second, asymptomatic (“silent”) myocardial infarction, pericardial calcifications and patchy pulmonary infiltrations make another underlying etiology more likely.
questions.hint: Generalized pitting edema, jugular venous distention, paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration (Kussmaul sign), and pericardial calcifications are all suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, abdominal fullness, and pedal edema for 3 months. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and is currently receiving therapy with isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 96/70 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. There is jugular venous distention. The jugular venous pressure rises with inspiration. Breath sounds are decreased at the lung base bilaterally. Cardiac examination reveals an early diastolic sound over the left sternal border. The abdomen is distended and a shifting dullness test is positive. An ECG shows low-amplitude QRS complexes. Chest x-ray shows small pleural effusions bilaterally and calcifications over the left cardiac silhouette. Echocardiography shows a 40% decrease in the velocity of peak diastolic blood flow across the mitral valve during inspiration. Cardiac catheterization shows elevated right ventricular diastolic pressure with characteristic dip-and-plateau waveform. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An implantable cardioverter defibrillator is recommended for patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy at risk for sudden cardiac death (e.g., history of cardiac arrest, family history of sudden cardiac death). Although obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may cause dyspnea and hypotension, as seen in this patient, it does not typically cause peripheral edema, Kussmaul sign, or a low-amplitude QRS complex. Additionally, this patient is missing typical signs of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, including: exertional angina; syncope; a jerky, biphasic pulse; a heaving, double apical impulse; systolic murmur; an S3 or S4; and/or evidence of arrhythmias.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid therapy is an alternative treatment for acute pericarditis in patients who have a contraindication to NSAIDs. It is not considered a first-line treatment due to systemic side effects and concern for an increased rate of recurrence of acute pericarditis when corticosteroids are administered. Furthermore, acute pericarditis usually presents with chest pain and a pericardial friction rub, both of which are absent in this patient. Additionally, acute pericarditis usually resolves within 6 weeks, but this patient has had symptoms for 3 months. An ECG would also show a concave-shaped ST elevation with or without PR depression, and unlike this patient, changes in the QRS complex would not be present.

C) INCORRECT:

Colchicine therapy is indicated for the treatment of acute pericarditis as it alleviates symptoms and reduces the rate of recurrence. However, acute pericarditis usually manifests with chest pain and a pericardial friction rub, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, acute pericarditis also usually resolves within six weeks, whereas this patient has had symptoms for three months. An ECG would also show diffuse, concave-shaped ST elevations with or without PR depressions, and changes in the QRS complex would not be present.

D) CORRECT:

Pericardiectomy, along with the treatment of any underlying condition (i.e., this patient's tuberculosis), is the recommended approach for constrictive pericarditis. In constrictive pericarditis, a thick, rigid, and fibrous pericardium compromises cardiac function, which is restored by the removal of the fibrotic pericardium. In patients without signs of chronic constrictive pericarditis (i.e., no pericardial calcifications, atrial fibrillation, hepatic dysfunction, anasarca, or cachexia), pharmacotherapy can be attempted first. This can include NSAIDs, colchicine, diuretics, corticosteroids, and immunomodulatory therapy; these measures should also be considered as adjuncts to pericardiectomy in chronic constrictive pericarditis.

In healthy individuals, the velocity of blood flow in the left side of the heart normally decreases with inspiration. However, in patients with constrictive pericarditis, this decrease in blood flow is exaggerated (> 25% decrease in diastolic flow across the mitral valve) because the rigid, fibrotic, shell-like pericardium impedes diastolic filling due to impaired relaxation of the left ventricle. In addition to these findings, an echocardiogram would show acoustic shadowing (caused by calcifications) and thickening of the pericardium.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with constrictive pericarditis, tachycardia is a compensatory mechanism that helps maintain cardiac output. Administering beta blockers such as metoprolol to such patients eliminates this compensatory function and would result in a poor outcome. Therefore, neither this nor any other drug that reduces heart rate is recommended for the management of constrictive pericarditis.

F) INCORRECT:

Heart transplantation is indicated as a last resort for restrictive cardiomyopathy, which presents with increased jugular venous pressure, Kussmaul sign, peripheral edema, ascites, and pleural effusion, as seen here. However, restrictive cardiomyopathy does not present with an exaggerated variation of blood flow during respiration, or a pericardial knock. Instead, a third and/or fourth heart sound would be heard. Although this condition may also present with low-amplitude QRS complex, it is usually seen with other ECG findings such as depolarization abnormalities (e.g., bundle branch block), ventricular hypertrophy, atrioventricular conduction alteration, and/or pathologic Q waves, none of which are present in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is the treatment for cardiac tamponade. This patient has a history of tuberculosis, which may cause pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Although cardiac tamponade would manifest with some of this patient's features – e.g., tachycardia, jugular venous distention, low-amplitude QRS complexes, hypotension, and an exaggerated variation of blood flow with respiration – it would also cause other features that are absent (e.g., muffled heart sounds, chest pain). Additionally, acute cardiac tamponade does not cause Kussmaul sign or a pericardial knock.
questions.hint: This patient with tuberculosis and dyspnea, ascites (distended abdomen, shifting dullness), and peripheral edema has a positive Kussmaul sign (increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration) and a pericardial knock (early diastolic sound over the left sternal border). These features along with calcifications on chest x-ray and an exaggerated respiratory variation of blood flow on echocardiography indicate constrictive pericarditis, which may be confirmed by a positive square root sign on cardiac catheterization (dip-and-plateau waveform).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a dry cough and severe chest pain beginning that morning. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with inferior wall myocardial infarction and was treated with stent implantation of the right coronary artery. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, and enalapril. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations. Serum studies show a troponin I of 0.2 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade can result from cardiac wall rupture, a complication of myocardial infarction. Cardiac tamponade would result in acute-onset chest pain and tachypnea, as in this patient, and ventricular free wall rupture can also result in increased troponin levels. However, patients with cardiac tamponade would also have features such as dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, and increased jugular venous pressure. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds rather than a pericardial rub would be heard. An ECG would show low voltage complexes, electrical alternans, and, possibly, tall precordial T waves. Moreover, rupture of the cardiac wall typically occurs within 2 weeks after an MI and is more commonly seen in anterior and/or lateral wall infarcts than with inferior wall infarcts.

B) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis has, on rare occasions, been reported after MI. However, it is a late complication that develops months to years after MI. Moreover, it would manifest with edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, hypotension, increased jugular venous pressure, a pericardial knock, the Kussmaul sign, and pulsus paradoxus, none of which are seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is a risk factor for aortic dissection, which manifests with acute-onset chest pain. ST elevations and increased troponin levels can also be present if the dissection extends proximally and causes coronary artery occlusion. However, PCI-associated aortic dissection typically occurs during or immediately after the procedure. Moreover, chest pain in aortic dissection is characteristically described as a “tearing” pain that radiates to the back, and features such as fever, cough, or a pericardial rub would not be expected. Instead, findings such as asymmetrical blood pressure readings, pulse deficits/delays, and/or hypotension are usually present.

D) INCORRECT:

Reinfarction, which is an important consideration in any patient with a recent MI, can manifest with acute-onset chest pain, tachypnea, increased troponin levels, and ST elevations. A dry cough (cardiac asthma) may also be present in some patients with MI. However, a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration would not be expected in reinfarction. Moreover, the ST elevations would be localized to certain leads, in contrast to the diffuse ST elevations in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Early infarct-associated pericarditis can manifest with fever, tachypnea, chest pain, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST-elevation on ECG. However, early infarct-associated pericarditis typically occurs within a few days after MI, whereas this patient's MI occurred 2 months ago.

F) CORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome), a type of postcardiac injury syndrome, usually occurs 2–10 weeks after MI due to immune-complex mediated damage (type III hypersensitivity reaction) in the pericardium. The exact mechanism of immune-complex formation in Dressler syndrome is not completely understood, but the release of neo-antigens from the infarcted myocardium is suspected to play a role. Patients typically present with features of acute pericarditis such as fever, tachypnea, chest pain that is worse during inspiration and relieved by leaning forward, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), a pericardial rub, increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG. Dressler syndrome may also cause pericardial effusion.

Dressler syndrome is treated with NSAIDs, preferably high-dose aspirin.

G) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) can manifest with acute-onset tachypnea, cough, low-grade fever, chest pain, increased troponin levels, and ST elevations on ECG. However, the ST elevations would primarily affect the right precordial (V1–V4) and inferior leads (II, III, aVF), in contrast to the diffuse ST elevations seen in this patient. Moreover, in a patient without tachycardia, hemoptysis, previous venous thromboembolism, clinical features of deep vein thrombosis (e.g., lower limb edema), and/or certain risk factors (e.g., surgery or immobilization in the past 4 weeks, malignancy), the Wells score for PE is low. A different diagnosis is much more likely in this patient given the presence of a pericardial rub.
questions.hint: The timing of this patient's symptoms in relation to his recent myocardial infarction (MI), the high-pitched scratching sound heard on auscultation, and the presence of diffuse ST elevations suggest a particular diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain for the past 3 hours. He reports that he can only take shallow breaths because deep inspiration worsens the pain. He also says that the pain increases with coughing. Two weeks ago, he underwent cardiac catheterization for an acute myocardial infarction. Current medications include aspirin, ticagrelor, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.1°F), pulse is 55/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound heard best when the patient is sitting upright and during expiration. An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations and ST depression in aVR and V1. Echocardiography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Heparin infusion is indicated for acute MI, which is an important differential diagnosis considering this patient's current chest pain and history of MI. However, an acute MI would not explain the diffuse ST elevations, friction rub, and the normal findings on echocardiography.

B) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin and ceftriaxone should be administered if purulent pericarditis is suspected. Patients with purulent pericarditis present with fever, chest pain, a friction rub, and diffuse ST elevations. However, echocardiography would show fluid in the pericardial sac. This patient also has no history that would predispose him to pericardial infection (i.e., pneumonia, endocarditis, or surgery).

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone can be used to treat acute pericarditis and Dressler syndrome, but it is only used in situations in which the first-line treatment is not sufficient.

D) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin would be a useful treatment in the setting of acute MI. This patient's chest pain and history of MI make reinfarction an important differential diagnosis. In the case of acute MI, though, the pattern of ST elevations on ECG would be expected to follow a specific distribution and no friction rub would be present. Furthermore, the findings on echocardiography would most likely not be normal.

E) CORRECT:

NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for Dressler syndrome because they provide pain relief and have antiinflammatory properties. Aspirin is usually preferred over other NSAIDs because it is indicated for secondary prophylaxis after an acute MI. Combining aspirin with another NSAID increases the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and kidney injury. The higher dosage of aspirin is maintained until symptoms resolve (usually 3–4 weeks), then tapered to the standard prophylaxis dosage. Rare complications of Dressler syndrome include pericardial effusion, pericardial tamponade, and constrictive pericarditis.

Dressler syndrome is an autoimmune response to cardiac muscle cells that occurs > 1 week after MI. This process is distinct from acute post-MI pericarditis, which occurs within 1 week of the event and is caused by an infarction located very close to the pericardium that causes direct irritation. The treatment of post-MI pericarditis is usually supportive; NSAIDs (except for aspirin) should be avoided for 7–10 days after an acute MI.

F) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is part of the treatment plan for purulent pericarditis and pericardial effusion, both of which manifest with symptoms similar to those seen in this patient (i.e., chest pain and dyspnea). Dressler syndrome can manifest with effusion. However, this patient's echocardiogram did not reveal any pericardial fluid, which would make pericardiocentesis unnecessary.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of acute pericarditis (pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub, fever, tachypnea, diffuse ST elevations on ECG), which in combination with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) 2 weeks prior, are consistent with post-cardiac injury syndrome, also known as Dressler syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of sharp chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. The pain worsens when she coughs, breathes deeply, or lies down. She has had a mild fever and a cough for the past 2 days. She takes ibuprofen for hip and knee pain, which started 4 months ago. Examination shows a symmetric, erythematous rash on her nose and cheeks, and erythematous patches with scaling and plugged follicles over her hands. Cardiovascular evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Increased distension of jugular veins during inspiration
18 mm Hg decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration
High-pitched pericardial sound occurring slightly earlier than a third heart sound
Triphasic scratchy heart sound of varying intensity
Jugular venous pulsation visible 9 cm above the sternal angle
Holosystolic blowing murmur heard best at the apex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Kussmaul sign is classically seen in right ventricular infarction, restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis, and tricuspid stenosis. Constrictive pericarditis may occur with SLE but would be characterized by signs of decreased cardiac output such as fatigue and tachycardia. It would also take months to years to develop. The patient's acute presentation with pleuritic chest pain, cough, and fever is more consistent with acute pericarditis, in which case the Kussmaul sign would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

A decrease of 18 mm Hg in systolic blood pressure during inspiration suggests pulsus paradoxus, which may be seen in cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis, and in noncardiac diseases such as asthma, COPD, and tension pneumothorax. Although SLE-associated pericarditis can be associated with a pericardial effusion, it rarely progresses to tamponade. Furthermore, other findings of cardiac tamponade, including dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia, and jugular venous distention, would be expected. Constrictive pericarditis is also rarely associated with SLE and would cause signs of decreased cardiac output (fatigue) and fluid overload (jugular venous distention, Kussmaul sign).

C) INCORRECT:

Pericardial knock is a high-pitched, early-diastolic sound in patients with constrictive pericarditis. Constrictive pericarditis may occur with SLE but would be characterized by signs of decreased cardiac output such as fatigue and tachycardia. It would also take months to years to develop. The patient's acute presentation with pleuritic chest pain, cough, and fever is more consistent with acute pericarditis, in which case the Kussmaul sign would not be expected.

D) CORRECT:

A triphasic scratchy or squeaky heart sound on auscultation suggests a pericardial friction rub, which is highly specific for pericarditis. Acute pericarditis typically manifests with fever and pleuritic chest pain that is usually sharp in nature, improves on sitting and leaning forward, and often radiates to the shoulder. It is the most common cardiac manifestation of SLE, occurring in ∼ 25% of patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated jugular venous pulsation can be seen in cardiac tamponade or constrictive pericarditis, both of which are uncommon in SLE. Furthermore, other findings of cardiac tamponade, including dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia, and jugular venous distention, would be expected. Constrictive pericarditis would cause signs of decreased cardiac output (fatigue) and fluid overload (jugular venous distention, Kussmaul sign).

F) INCORRECT:

Holosystolic blowing murmur best heard at the apex suggests mitral regurgitation. Libman-Sacks endocarditis, which is caused by noninfectious verrucous vegetations and is seen in SLE, favors the mitral valve and can result in mitral regurgitation. Most patients, however, are asymptomatic. This patient's fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain are more consistent with acute pericarditis, which is also the most common cardiac manifestation of SLE.
questions.hint: Joint pain, malar rash, and a discoid rash (erythematous patches with scaling and follicular plugging) should immediately raise suspicion of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The acute onset of low-grade fever and pleuritic chest pain that is aggravated by lying down (and thus improved by sitting up) is suggestive of acute pericarditis, the most common cardiovascular manifestation of SLE.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intense retrosternal chest pain for the last 3 days. The pain is worse with breathing or coughing, and improves while sitting upright. She also reports a mild fever and shortness of breath. She was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease secondary to lupus nephritis 12 years ago and has been on hemodialysis since then, but she missed her last two appointments because of international travel. She also underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention 8 months ago for a myocardial infarction. She takes azathioprine after hemodialysis. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally with normal breath sounds. Cardiac examination reveals a high-pitched scratching that obscures both heart sounds. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Cardiac enzyme levels and anti-dsDNA antibodies are within normal limits. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows Q waves in the anterior leads. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?

choices.text: Purulent exudate in the pericardial space
Elevated serum levels of nitrogenous waste

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Certain medications can cause pericarditis, including methotrexate (also used to treat SLE), doxorubicin, hydralazine, or isoniazid. This patient takes azathioprine, an immunosuppressant that is not associated with pericarditis and is unlikely to cause her presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Serositis of the pericardium is one of the most common cardiac manifestations of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and should always be considered in a patient with SLE who presents with chest pain. However, unlike in this patient, SLE pericarditis usually manifests with ECG changes (i.e., diffuse ST elevations and PR depressions in all leads except aVR) due to involvement of the epicardium. Additionally, this patient's normal anti-dsDNA antibodies do not suggest an active SLE flare.

Dressler syndrome (postmyocardial infarction syndrome) is a type of pericarditis that can occur 2–10 weeks after MI, possibly resulting from immune complex formation within the pericardium and can manifest with low-grade fever, pericardial friction rub, and chest pain. However, this patient has normal cardiac enzymes and no diffuse ST elevations on ECG, making Dressler syndrome unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Myocardial infarction (MI) can cause pericarditis via two mechanisms. Acute pericarditis can manifest as benign and self-limited inflammation of the pericardium within 24–72 hours of a transmural MI. Dressler syndrome (postmyocardial infarction syndrome) is a more serious type of pericarditis that can occur 2–10 weeks after MI, possibly resulting from immune complex formation within the pericardium. Both conditions most commonly manifest with low-grade fever, pericardial friction rub, and chest pain. However, this patient has normal cardiac enzymes and no diffuse ST elevations on ECG, making MI-related pericarditis unlikely. Moreover, her MI occurred 8 months ago, and there is no evidence of current cardiac ischemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Purulent pericarditis refers to localized infection of the pericardial space (usually bacterial or fungal) and is characterized by purulent exudate. This condition is rare and usually associated with recent thoracic surgery, malignancy, immune suppression, or preexisting pericardial disease. Affected individuals typically present with very high fever and ECG changes (classically, diffuse ST elevations and PR depressions), which are absent in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with a history of chronic kidney disease and missed dialysis sessions, which makes uremia the most likely cause of her symptoms. In patients with end-stage renal disease, inadequate clearance of uremic toxins can lead to pericardial inflammation. Pericardial inflammation due to uremia is less likely than other types of pericarditis to manifest with diffuse ST elevations and PR depressions on ECG, possibly because epicardial injury is minimal. Urgent hemodialysis is indicated to remove the accumulated toxins and resolve inflammation.

Some sources distinguish between uremic pericarditis, which occurs before or up to 8 weeks after starting dialysis, and dialysis-associated pericarditis, which can manifest in patients undergoing long-term treatment. Both conditions are caused by inadequate toxin clearance and are managed similarly regardless of when dialysis was initiated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with pleuritic and positional chest pain, dyspnea, and a pericardial friction rub, which is consistent with acute pericarditis. The pathologic Q waves in the ECG are explained by her previous infarction.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of increasing shortness of breath. He has also had chest pain that is exacerbated by deep inspiration. He has had recurrent episodes of pain in his fingers for the past 2 years. Two years ago, he was treated for a deep vein thrombosis. He has hypertension and anxiety. Current medications include enalapril, St. John's wort, and ibuprofen. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctiva. There is tenderness to palpation of the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands. Heart sounds are distant. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.9 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4200/mm3



Platelet count
330,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

4.3 mEq/L


Antinuclear antibodies
1: 320


Anti-Sm antibodies
positive


Anti-CCP antibodies
negative


An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on this patient's ECG?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudo right bundle branch block refers to an ECG finding seen in some inherited arrhythmia syndromes (e.g., Brugada syndrome) and in some patients with left-sided accessory pathways. Both conditions are often found incidentally but may manifest with ventricular tachyarrhythmias, syncope, or sudden cardiac death. Pseudo right bundle branch block is not consistent with pericarditis or pericardial effusion.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 50 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼83/min
– Right axis deviation: R < S in I, R > S in aVF
– ST elevation ≥ 2 mm and a negative T wave in V1 and V2 (red overlay). The shape of ST elevation seen in V1 is described as “coved.”
– Pseudo-RBBB: The ST changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V1.

Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V1–V3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolongation of the QT interval can be a seen in hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and inherited long QT syndrome and may be a side effect of various medications. This patient has no symptoms of hypomagnesemia (e.g., tetany, spasm, cramps), his serum potassium is normal, and none of his current medications would have a significant effect on the QT interval. Pericarditis and pericardial effusion does not cause an increased QT interval.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Regular sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 107/min (tachycardia)
- Normal cardiac axis (zoom-box)
- Normal PR interval (approx.160 ms)
- Negative T-wave in III (green circles), T-wave not clearly discernible in V3
- Prolonged (corrected) QT interval with approx. 494 ms

These findings suggest a long QT syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Second-degree AV block is a conduction abnormality that may occur in a variety of diseases (e.g., structural heart disease, electrolyte disorders). While AV blocks can lower cardiac output and consequently cause shortness of breath, most patients are asymptomatic. Less commonly, second-degree AV block manifests with dizziness or syncope (Stokes Adams attacks). Findings in second-degree AV block include irregular heartbeat and bradycardia; there are no radiological findings in isolated AV blocks. Pericarditis with pericardial effusion does not typically cause AV blocks.
Image Description:

ECG strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular P waves at a rate of ∼80/min (green overlay)
– There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.

D) INCORRECT:

A deep Q wave on ECG can be seen in the intermediate or chronic stages of myocardial infarction (MI). While MI can also manifest with chest pain and shortness of breath, the onset of symptoms is usually acute and the pain is often described as pressure, squeezing, or tightness in the chest. In some patients with MI, a new murmur can be observed on auscultation, but not diminished heart sounds. In MI, an x-ray may show signs of decompensation like pulmonary edema. Pericarditis and pericardial effusion does not cause deep Q waves on ECG.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: 90/min
– Left axis deviation (R wave > S wave in lead I, R < S in aVF and II)
– ST elevation in V2–V4 (example indicated by ST)
– Pathological Q waves in V1–V4 (example indicated by Q)
– T-wave inversion in V1–V4 (example indicated by T)
– Reduced R wave amplitude in V4–V6 (example indicated by R)

These findings are consistent with the intermediate stage of an anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction.

E) CORRECT:

Electrical alternans is an ECG finding that is highly specific to large pericardial effusions. This finding is characterized by cyclical changes (alterations) in the axis or amplitude of consecutive QRS complexes, which can be attributed to the swinging motion of the beating heart surrounded by pericardial fluid. In addition, ECG in patients with large pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade typically shows sinus tachycardia and low voltage recording.

Management of pericardial effusion depends on the patient's hemodynamic stability: In stable patients, transthoracic echocardiography should be used to confirm the diagnosis. In unstable patients and those in cardiac arrest with suspected tamponade, pericardiocentesis should not be delayed for diagnostic confirmation.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Narrow-complex tachycardia with a ventricular rate of approx. 150/min
- Likely atrial fibrillation (irregular RR intervals, no definitive P waves)
- Normal cardiac axis (R > S in both I and aVF)
- QRS voltage is low, and consecutive R waves alternate in height (electrical alternans, red lines)

The combination of tachycardia, low QRS voltage, and electrical alternans is highly suggestive of a large pericardial effusion.

F) INCORRECT:

The S1Q3T3 pattern is an ECG sign that indicates right-heart strain. Despite its low sensitivity and specificity, S1Q3T3 pattern is classically associated with pulmonary embolism (PE). This patient's history of DVT is a risk factor for PE, which can manifest with shortness of breath, tachycardia, and pleuritic chest pain. However, auscultation would reveal either normal or decreased breath sounds, not distant heart sounds. In PE, chest x-rays are most commonly normal or show nonspecific findings such as atelectasis or pleural effusion. Rare findings that are more specific to PE include Hampton hump and Westermark sign, neither of which are present in this patient's x-ray. Pericarditis and pericardial effusion does not typically cause right-heart strain and an S1Q3T3 pattern.
Image Description:

12 channel ECG with sinus rhythm, negative T-wave in V1-V5, and S1Q3T3 pattern (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III and negative T-wave in lead III).

Findings of a negative T-wave in the anterior leads and an S1Q3T3 pattern suggest an acute pulmonary embolism.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, distant heart sounds, tachycardia, pleuritic chest pain, and a chest x-ray showing an enlarged cardiac silhouette with a globular "water bottle-shaped" heart (water bottle sign) make pericarditis with pericardial effusion the most likely diagnosis. In the setting of arthralgia, anemia, leukopenia, positive antinuclear antibodies, positive anti-Sm antibodies, and a history of deep vein thrombosis indicative of antiphospholipid syndrome, this patient's pericardial effusion is most likely due to underlying systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. For the past 5 days, he has had intermittent stabbing pain in the middle of his chest that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has also had a runny nose and a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale and sweaty. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min. Blood pressure is 107/72 mm Hg during expiration and 86/65 mm Hg during inspiration. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Dilation of the atria and ventricles
Accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity
Tear in the inner layer of the aorta
Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the atria and ventricles is characteristic of a number of cardiac diseases, including dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). DCM can manifest with both right heart failure (jugular vein distention, peripheral edema) and left heart failure (hypotension, dyspnea) and it is commonly preceded by a recent history of viral upper respiratory infection. However, an episode of stabbing chest pain with inspiration, which was followed by worsening shortness of breath and pulsus paradoxus and preceded by flu-like symptoms, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity (pleural effusion) can occur in a variety of conditions, including congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome, as well as infections and malignancies. Depending on the underlying disease, pleural effusion can manifest with pleuritic chest pain (worsening with inspiration), dry cough, progressive dyspnea, jugular vein distention, and peripheral edema. However, this patient lacks other typical features of pleural effusion, such as decreased breath sounds, dullness on percussion, and asymmetrical chest expansion. Furthermore, pulsus paradoxus would not be consistent with pleural effusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery occlusion is characteristic of myocardial infarction (MI), which can manifest with chest pain, dyspnea, tachycardia, and sweating. Moreover, acute ventricular dysfunction as a result of MI could result in peripheral edema, jugular venous distention, and hypotension. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia puts him at increased risk for MI. The chest pain in acute MI, however, is often described as squeezing and typically radiates to the jaw or left arm. Moreover, the combination of an episode of stabbing chest pain with inspiration and pulsus paradoxus in this patient, which was preceded by flu-like symptoms, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A tear in the inner layer of the aorta is characteristic of aortic dissection, which can manifest with stabbing chest pain, progressive dyspnea, pallor, and sweating. Although high blood pressure is a more common finding in patients with aortic dissection, patients may have low blood pressure if the dissection involves the proximal ascending aorta, or if it results in aortic rupture and hemorrhage. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia puts him at increased risk for aortic dissection. The chest pain in aortic dissection, however, is described as sudden, severe, and tearing, with radiation to the back. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of aortic dissection, such as asymmetrical blood pressure and pulse readings between limbs, syncope, and confusion.

E) CORRECT:

Preceded by an episode of flu-like symptoms, this patient's history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up is suggestive of acute pericarditis. This patient most likely has cardiac tamponade as a complication of acute pericarditis. Cardiac tamponade can occur if increased amounts of inflammatory fluid are secreted into the pericardial space, compressing the cardiac chambers. This leads to decreased ventricular diastolic filling and decreased cardiac output. Other common causes of cardiac tamponade include aortic dissection and chest trauma.

Hemodynamically unstable patients should be treated with ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis or surgical drainage in order to decompress the pericardium.

F) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of a pulmonary artery is characteristic of pulmonary embolism (PE), which can manifest with pleuritic chest pain (worsening with inspiration) and progressive dyspnea. Moreover, right heart failure as a result of PE would result in peripheral edema and jugular venous distention. However, a history of symptoms of upper respiratory infection, followed by an episode of intermittent sharp chest pain and pulsus paradoxus (which is rarely seen in patients with PE), is more suggestive of a different diagnosis. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of PE, such as cough, decreased breath sounds, symptoms of deep vein thrombosis, or a history of recent immobilization.

G) INCORRECT:

Fibrous thickening of the pericardium is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis, which can occur as a complication of acute pericarditis. Constrictive pericarditis can manifest with signs of both right heart failure (jugular vein distention, peripheral edema) and left heart failure (hypotension, dyspnea), as well as pulsus paradoxus. However, chest pain is not a typical finding in patients with constrictive pericarditis. Moreover, the patient lacks other typical features of constrictive pericarditis, such as fatigue and a pericardial knock on auscultation. Additionally, constrictive pericarditis is usually a late complication of acute pericarditis and would not be expected only 5 days after the onset of symptoms.
questions.hint: Pulsus paradoxus (significant decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration) and symptoms of heart failure (worsening shortness of breath, jugular venous distention, peripheral edema) suggest a particular condition.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and sharp substernal chest pain. The chest pain worsens on inspiration and on lying down. The patient was diagnosed with breast cancer 2 months ago and was treated with mastectomy followed by adjuvant radiation therapy. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include tamoxifen, valsartan, and pitavastatin. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but quit after being diagnosed with breast cancer. Her pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a scratching sound best heard at the left lower sternal border. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and ST segment elevations in leads I, II, avF, and V1–V6. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Dystrophic calcification of the mitral valve
Embolic occlusion of a pulmonary artery
Thrombotic occlusion of a coronary artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radiation-induced valvular disease is a late complication most commonly affecting the aortic and mitral valves. Pathologic changes include dystrophic calcification, focal thickening of the valvular endocardium, and fibrosis of the (mitral) valve leaflet. However, radiation-induced valvular disease often progresses slowly and is usually asymptomatic, with it taking at least 5 years for symptoms to appear. Moreover, valvular disease would not explain this patient's ECG findings.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of malignancy and current hormonal therapy with tamoxifen increases her risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Patients with PE can present with pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath, and tachycardia, which are seen in this patient; however, this patient lacks evidence of DVT, which would take the form of leg swelling, erythema, and pain on dorsiflexion. Additionally, her ECG findings are not consistent with PE, which typically manifests with evidence of right ventricular strain (e.g., T-wave inversion in leads V1–V4).

C) CORRECT:

This patient's history of breast radiation therapy, shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and sharp substernal chest pain that worsens in the supine position make acute radiation-induced pericarditis the most likely diagnosis. This diagnosis is further supported by her friction rub (triphasic scratching sound) and ECG showing diffuse ST segment elevation. Pericardial involvement is a common adverse effect of radiation therapy of the chest. In the acute setting, exposure to high doses of radiation causes cellular injury, which leads to the release of inflammatory mediators and cytokines, resulting in neutrophilic infiltration of the pericardium.

Several years after radiation therapy, individuals may develop constrictive pericarditis, which is characterized by fibrotic thickening of the pericardium and manifests with symptoms of fluid overload. Other long-term cardiovascular adverse effects of radiation therapy include cardiomyopathy, valvular heart disease, coronary artery disease, and conduction abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

Subendothelial fibrosis of the coronary arteries is a rare complication of radiation therapy of the chest that typically occurs many years after exposure to radiation. It is caused by radiation-induced endothelial damage, which heals by fibrosis, resulting in stenosis of the coronary arteries. Patients usually present with features of stable angina, e.g., exertional, pressure-like, retrosternal chest pain that improves with rest. While an acute coronary syndrome is a possibility in this patient, the timing of her symptoms (two months after radiation therapy), nature of her chest pain (sharp, worse while lying down), abnormal heart sound, and ECG results (diffuse ST segment elevation) are not consistent with subendothelial fibrosis of the coronary arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by fibrotic thickening of the pericardium and is a complication of radiation therapy. However, radiation-induced constrictive pericarditis is a late complication that progresses slowly and manifests many years after radiation therapy with signs and symptoms of fluid overload, e.g., jugular venous distention, peripheral edema.

F) INCORRECT:

Radiation-induced myocardial fibrosis is characterized by fibrotic replacement of myocardiocytes in response to the destruction of capillaries. Progressive fibrosis ultimately leads to decreased elasticity and compliance, leading to left ventricular dysfunction (cardiomyopathy). Radiation-induced cardiomyopathy manifests with features of congestive heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), e.g., orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, which are not seen in this patient. Moreover, radiation-induced cardiomyopathy progresses slowly and usually takes at least 5 years to become symptomatic.

G) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of a coronary artery is the pathophysiologic mechanism of myocardial infarction (MI), which typically manifests with chest pain and ST segment elevation on ECG, which is seen in this patient. However, this patient's scratching heart sound and diffuse ST segment elevation (not limited to the territory of a single coronary artery) suggest a different diagnosis. Additionally, the character of her chest pain (i.e., sharp, worsens when laying down) is atypical for myocardial infarction, which usually manifests with retrosternal chest pain and chest tightness.
questions.hint: Radiation therapy of the breast is often accompanied by local damage and inflammation of tissue adjacent to the original tumor, including the lungs and heart. Some of the adverse effects associated with radiation therapy may occur acutely, while others take months to years to develop.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States from Haiti comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. For the past few days, he has also had difficulty lying flat due to trouble breathing. Over the past year, he has had intermittent fever, night sweats, and cough but he has not been seen by a physician for evaluation of these symptoms. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). An x-ray of the chest is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Elimination of S2 heart sound splitting with inspiration
Head bobbing in synchrony with heart beat
Painless erythematous lesions on palms or soles
Prominent "a" wave on jugular venous pressure tracing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is a physiological finding heard during inspiration. It is caused by the early closure of the aortic valve (A2) in relation to the pulmonary valve (P2) when intrathoracic pressure is decreased. In conditions such as aortic stenosis (AS), ventricular septal defect with Eisenmenger syndrome, and left bundle branch block, elimination of S2 splitting can occur because A2 is delayed and superimposed on P2. Although severe, long-standing aortic stenosis can result in fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), chronic AS is not associated with fever or night sweats but with symptoms such as syncope, palpitations, and angina. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications but an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

B) INCORRECT:

Rhythmic nodding or bobbing of the head in synchronicity with the heartbeat is referred to as de Musset sign, a typical feature of chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). AR may present with progressively worsening fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema). However, chronic AR is not associated with fever or night sweats, and an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, but rather a prominent aortic root and an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

C) INCORRECT:

Painless erythematous lesions on the palms or soles (Janeway lesions) are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, fever, and night sweats. However, the symptoms of IE have an acute or subacute onset (days to weeks), whereas this patient had fever, night sweats, and a cough for a year before developing dyspnea and fatigue. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, and IE is almost always associated with the development of a new heart murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

On a jugular venous pressure tracing, the “a” wave is caused by atrial contraction in late diastole. A prominent “a” wave is a sign of increased atrial contraction pressure due to restricted filling of the right ventricle (e.g., tricuspid valve stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, cardiac tamponade). In constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular filling is only impaired when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. As a result, all right ventricular filling rapidly occurs in early diastole, producing a prominent and deep x descent and y descent on venous pressure tracing rather than a prominent “a” wave.
Image Description:

A normal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is composed of:
- a wave: atrial contraction
- c wave: tricuspid valve closure
- x descent: atrial relaxation
- v wave: venous refilling of the atria
- y descent: passive filling of right ventricle when the tricuspid valve opens

Common abnormalities of the JVP waveform include:
- Constrictive pericarditis: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure) with a prominent x (exaggerated atrial relaxation) and y (early rapid ventricular filling) descent
- Cardiac tamponade: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure), a prominent x descent (exaggerated atrial relaxation), and a blunt or absent y descent (minimal ventricular filling)
- Tricuspid regurgitation: prominent v wave as the blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium during ventricular systole (atrial diastole), increasing interatrial pressure and volume
- Tricuspid stenosis: giant a wave due to high right atrial systolic pressure
- Atrial septal defect: v wave ≥ a wave due to the left-to-right shunting of blood
- Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block: cannon a waves due to the loss of AV synchronization and contraction of the atria against a closed tricuspid valve
- Atrial fibrillation: absent a waves due to ineffective contraction of the atria

E) CORRECT:

Normally, the decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration expands the compliant right ventricle, resulting in a decrease in jugular venous pressure. In constrictive pericarditis, compliance of the right ventricle is decreased and the right ventricle fails to expand during inspiration. This, alongside a possible increase in baseline jugular venous pressure in constrictive pericarditis due to restricted right ventricular filling during late diastole, leads to an increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration, and therefore, jugular venous distention on inspiration. This phenomenon, which is called Kussmaul sign, can also be seen in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Management options for constrictive pericarditis include NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids, pericardiectomy, and treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., antitubercular or immunomodulatory therapy).

In cardiac tamponade without underlying pericarditis (e.g., traumatic hemopericardium), the jugular venous pressure is increased as a result of impaired right ventricular filling. However, the right ventricle is still compliant and a decrease in intrathoracic pressure can be transmitted to the right ventricle across the fluid-filled pericardial sac. Kussmaul sign would not be expected in traumatic cardiac tamponade.

F) INCORRECT:

A crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped) systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space is a common finding in aortic stenosis (AS). While severe, long-standing AS can result in chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), fever and night sweats are not commonly seen. Finally, symptoms such as syncope, angina, and palpitations are expected in chronic AS, and x-ray would show an enlarged cardiac silhouette rather than the pericardial calcifications seen here.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.
questions.hint: New-onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue alongside pericardial thickening and calcifications on x-ray indicate constrictive pericarditis. In this patient with an immigration history from an endemic region and a prolonged history of night sweats, fever, and cough, the most likely etiology of constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States from Indonesia comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and swollen extremities for the past 3 months. He has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss and intermittent fevers over the last 6 months. Examination shows pitting pedal edema and abdominal distension. Abdominal pressure over the right upper quadrant produces persistent distention of the jugular veins. An x-ray of the chest shows cavernous infiltrates in the left and right-upper lobes and a calcified cardiac silhouette. Cardiovascular examination is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Absent jugular venous pulse y descent

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The y descent of the jugular venous pulse waveform corresponds to the emptying of the right atrium following the opening of the tricuspid valve. Absent y descent would indicate resistance to all phases of diastolic filling, which is seen in cardiac tamponade. In constrictive pericarditis, the early phase of diastolic filling is unchanged, but the mid-late phase is met with resistance. This, coupled with the high jugular venous distention of chronic venous congestion, produces a prominent y descent that is accentuated in the early phase as filling drops rapidly from a higher peak pressure.
Image Description:

A normal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is composed of:
- a wave: atrial contraction
- c wave: tricuspid valve closure
- x descent: atrial relaxation
- v wave: venous refilling of the atria
- y descent: passive filling of right ventricle when the tricuspid valve opens

Common abnormalities of the JVP waveform include:
- Constrictive pericarditis: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure) with a prominent x (exaggerated atrial relaxation) and y (early rapid ventricular filling) descent
- Cardiac tamponade: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure), a prominent x descent (exaggerated atrial relaxation), and a blunt or absent y descent (minimal ventricular filling)
- Tricuspid regurgitation: prominent v wave as the blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium during ventricular systole (atrial diastole), increasing interatrial pressure and volume
- Tricuspid stenosis: giant a wave due to high right atrial systolic pressure
- Atrial septal defect: v wave ≥ a wave due to the left-to-right shunting of blood
- Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block: cannon a waves due to the loss of AV synchronization and contraction of the atria against a closed tricuspid valve
- Atrial fibrillation: absent a waves due to ineffective contraction of the atria

B) INCORRECT:

In acute pericarditis, inflammation of the pericardial layers can cause friction as they move during the cardiac cycle, creating an audible friction rub on cardiac auscultation. While a friction rub is characteristic of the acute phase of pericarditis, a different heart sound is pathognomonic for chronic constrictive pericarditis, in which the ventricles are working against a calcified and thickened pericardium.

C) CORRECT:

A pericardial knock is a high-pitched, early-diastolic sound that sounds like a premature S3. A pericardial knock is often heard on auscultation in constrictive pericarditis due to the abrupt halting of diastolic ventricular relaxation and filling by the rigid pericardial sac. In constrictive pericarditis, reduced ventricular filling leads to manifestations of reduced cardiac output (forward failure), such as fatigue and/or dyspnea, as well as those of fluid overload (backward failure), such as jugular venous distention, positive Kussmaul sign, hepatomegaly, and the clinical features seen in this patient.

While tuberculosis is the most likely underlying cause of constrictive pericarditis in this patient, other etiologies include prior cardiac surgery, radiation therapy to the chest, viral infection, and connective tissue diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

A fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by a late diastolic contraction of the atria and is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, and ischemic heart disease. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is an important differential diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis because it can manifest similarly. However, it does not cause calcification of the cardiac silhouette. An S4 is not a physical exam finding of constrictive pericarditis, most likely because the rigid pericardial sac impairs atrial contraction.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is characteristic of the prolonged left ventricular total ejection time seen in aortic stenosis (AS). AS would cause signs and symptoms of left heart failure, but not the symptoms of right heart failure seen in this patient. Furthermore, calcification in AS is limited to the aortic valve and does not involve the entire cardiac silhouette, as seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 is pathognomonic for atrial septal defect. Although patients with constrictive pericarditis may occasionally have wide splitting of S2 during inspiration due to a reduction in the left ventricular ejection time, they do not have fixed splitting of S2.
questions.hint: This patient's history of immigration from an endemic region, his clinical presentation of fever and weight loss, as well as the cavernous lesions seen on x-ray indicate tuberculosis. His dyspnea, pitting edema, abdominal distention, and positive hepatojugular reflux in the context of a calcified cardiac silhouette suggest constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of sharp, substernal chest pain that is worse with inspiration and relieved with leaning forward. He has also had nausea and myalgias. His father has coronary artery disease. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched rubbing sound between S1 and S2 that is best heard at the left sternal border. ECG shows depressed PR interval and diffuse ST elevations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dressler syndrome is an autoimmune complication that manifests as pericarditis weeks after myocardial infarction. This patient without coronary artery disease or past myocardial infarction is unlikely to develop this type of pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although substernal chest pain should raise concern for acute myocardial infarction (MI), this patient does not have risk factors for coronary artery disease (e.g., diabetes mellitus, tobacco use) aside from family history. Furthermore, acute MI does not manifest with positional chest pain, friction rub, or noncontiguous ST elevations. MI may cause pericarditis within 1–3 days (i.e., postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis), but this patient has no history of recent MI.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis is the most common cause of pericarditis in endemic countries. However, tuberculosis pericarditis is unlikely in a patient who has no characteristic symptoms (cough, weight loss, night sweats). Furthermore, he has no demographic risk factors (travel to endemic countries, work in hospitals/nursing homes, incarceration) nor medical risk factors (congenital or acquired immunodeficiency) of tuberculosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiovascular involvement is common in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), including pericarditis and endocarditis (Libman-Sacks). Pericarditis in patients with SLE is most commonly subclinical, noted only on echocardiogram. This patient presents with symptomatic pericarditis, has no signs of SLE, and has no family history of autoimmune disease.

E) CORRECT:

The most common causes of acute pericarditis are 1.) idiopathic (assumed viral etiology), followed by 2.) cases of confirmed viral etiology. The most common causes of viral pericarditis are coxsackievirus B and echovirus; other pathogens include hepatitis viruses, influenza virus, measles virus, mumps virus, varicella virus, and HIV.

Idiopathic cases are presumed to be viral because efforts to confirm etiology are not routinely pursued due to the expenses involved, the inaccessibility of pericardial tissue/fluid, and the time delay and inaccuracy of viral studies (e.g., culture, PCR, viral serology). In most cases, clinical management is not changed by these results.
questions.hint: Sharp, pleuritic, and positional chest pain and a pericardial friction rub in combination with an ECG showing diffuse ST elevations indicate acute pericarditis.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 64 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My chest hurts, especially when I take a deep breath.”
History of Present Illness: 


2-hour history of chest pain

pain described as “sharp”

Appearance: sitting forward at the edge of a hospital bed, uncomfortable
Neck: no jugular venous distension
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs; a scratching sound is best heard over the left sternal border; pain is not reproducible on palpation; pain is worse when the patient is lying back and improved by leaning forward

Abdominal: no tenderness, guarding, masses, bruits, or hepatosplenomegaly
Extremities: tenderness to palpation, stiffness, and swelling of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of the fingers; swan neck deformities and ulnar deviation of several fingers; firm, nontender nodules on the extensor aspects of the left forearm; no edema
Neurologic: alert and oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal neurologic deficits


An ECG is most likely to show which of the following findings in this patient?

choices.text: S waves in lead I, Q waves in lead III, and inverted T waves in lead III
Peaked T waves and ST segment elevations in leads V1-V6
Alternating high and low amplitude QRS complexes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ECG findings of S waves in lead I, Q waves in lead III, and inverted T waves in lead III represent the S1Q3T3 pattern that is associated with right ventricular strain due to pulmonary embolism (PE). PE can manifest with sharp and pleuritic chest pain. Though rheumatoid arthritis increases the risk of PE, this patient has no tachycardia, hemoptysis, symptoms of deep vein thrombosis, history of recent surgery or immobilization, or evidence of malignancy. Thus, her Wells score for PE is zero, which indicates that there is a low probability of PE in this patient. In addition, this condition is not associated with a pericardial friction rub.
Image Description:

12 channel ECG with sinus rhythm, negative T-wave in V1-V5, and S1Q3T3 pattern (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III and negative T-wave in lead III).

Findings of a negative T-wave in the anterior leads and an S1Q3T3 pattern suggest an acute pulmonary embolism.

B) CORRECT:

Diffuse, concave ST segment elevations in multiple leads are the typical ECG findings seen in patients with acute pericarditis. The ST segment elevations are typically present in all leads except for aVR and V1, which may show ST segment depressions. ECG may also show diffuse PR segment depressions. Though the most common cause of pericarditis is viral infection, the most likely etiology in this patient is her underlying diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. Management of nonbacterial pericarditis includes administration of NSAIDs and, in severe cases, glucocorticoids.

In contrast to the diffuse, concave ST segment elevations of pericarditis, ST segment elevations in ST segment elevation myocardial infarction typically have a convex morphology and are present in the leads that correspond to the perfusion territory of a specific coronary artery.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Rate ∼60/min
- Regular sinus rhythm
- Normal cardiac axis (R >S in I and aVF)
- Normal PR interval (∼140ms) and QTc (∼400ms)
- Narrow QRS complexes
- Diffuse concave ST elevation (in I, II, aVF, V3–V6) with reciprocal ST depression in aVR and V1 (red overlay).

These findings are consistent with acute pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

A sawtooth-appearance of P waves is the typical ECG finding seen in patients with atrial flutter, which can rarely manifest with chest pain. Most patients with this condition are asymptomatic. Other symptoms that may be present include palpitations, dizziness, syncope, and dyspnea, none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, this condition is not associated with a pericardial friction rub.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Atrial rate of ~ 375/min and a ventricular rate of ~100/min
- Irregularly irregular rhythm (variable AV block with 3:1 and 4:1 conduction in a nonfixed pattern)
- Normal axis (R > S in leads I and II, R < S in aVF)
- Sawtooth P wave morphology (flutter waves), seen best here in V1
- Normal QRS complex morphology

These findings are consistent with atrial flutter with a variable atrioventricular block.

D) INCORRECT:

Peaked T waves and ST segment elevations in leads V1–V6 are the typical ECG findings seen in patients with an ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) due to an occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. Though this patient's age and history of rheumatoid arthritis are risk factors for coronary artery disease, she lacks other major risk factors, such as type 2 diabetes mellitus, tobacco use, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Myocardial infarction (MI) can cause acute chest pain, but the pain is more likely to be described as dull or squeezing, rather than sharp and pleuritic. Moreover, acute MI would not explain this patient's pericardial friction rub. In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of MI, including dyspnea, nausea, vomiting, diaphoresis, and syncope.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 85/min
- Normal cardiac axis (leads I, II, and III positive, but difficult to interpret because of the ST changes)
- ST elevation in V2–V6, aVL, and slightly in I
- Reciprocal ST depression in leads II, III, and aVF

E) INCORRECT:

Alternating high and low amplitude QRS complexes (i.e., electrical alternans) are the characteristic ECG findings seen in patients with cardiac tamponade. This condition can cause chest pain, and this patient's history of rheumatoid arthritis and presentation of acute pericarditis are risk factors for the development of a pericardial effusion that can progress to tamponade. However, muffled heart sounds would be expected in both cardiac tamponade and significant pericardial effusion. Furthermore, other findings of cardiac tamponade include hypotension, jugular venous distention, and pulsus paradoxus, none of which are seen in this patient.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Narrow-complex tachycardia with a ventricular rate of approx. 150/min
- Likely atrial fibrillation (irregular RR intervals, no definitive P waves)
- Normal cardiac axis (R > S in both I and aVF)
- QRS voltage is low, and consecutive R waves alternate in height (electrical alternans, red lines)

The combination of tachycardia, low QRS voltage, and electrical alternans is highly suggestive of a large pericardial effusion.
questions.hint: This patient's acute-onset sharp and pleuritic chest pain, relief when leaning forward, and pericardial friction rub are highly suggestive of a diagnosis of acute pericarditis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 12 hours after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and substernal chest pain at rest; the pain is increased by inspiration. He has also had a nonproductive cough, fever, and malaise for the past 5 days. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins. Auscultation of the chest discloses bilateral basilar rales and muffled heart sounds. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia, diffuse ST segment elevation, low voltage QRS complexes, and fluctuating R wave amplitude. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Post-infarction fibrinous pericarditis typically occurs 1–3 days after a transmural myocardial infarction (MI) and can manifest with fever, inspiratory chest pain, dry cough, and diffuse ST elevation, as seen in this patient. However, this patient does not have a history of coronary artery disease or recent MI, making post-infarction fibrinous pericarditis unlikely. Rather, his 5-day history of cough, fever, and malaise suggests an infectious cause for the pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease manifests with fever and malaise, as seen in this patient. Myocarditis and myocardial infarction are known complications of this condition that can manifest with chest pain and features of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins). However, a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires further specific symptoms, such as erythema and edema of the hands and feet, polymorphous rash, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and oropharyngeal mucositis. Moreover, this condition most commonly affects children under the age of 5 years, so it is an unlikely diagnosis in a 55-year-old man.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever (RF) manifests with fever and malaise, as seen in this patient. Cardiac complications of RF include pancarditis and valvular heart disease, which can cause symptoms of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins). However, the typical ECG finding in RF is a prolonged PR interval, which is not seen here. Moreover, this patient does not have a history of untreated bacterial tonsillopharyngitis or other typical features of RF (e.g., migratory polyarthritis, subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea).

D) INCORRECT:

Dressler syndrome usually occurs 2–10 weeks after myocardial infarction (MI) due to immune complex-mediated damage in the pericardium. While this patient does present with signs and symptoms of acute pericarditis (e.g., fever, pleuritic chest pain, dry cough, and diffuse ST elevation), he does not have a history of coronary artery disease or past MI, making Dressler syndrome unlikely. Rather, his 5-day history of cough, fever, and malaise suggests an infectious cause for the pericarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis (IE) could explain this patient's fever, malaise, pleuritic chest pain, and features of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins).
