However, he presents with muffled heart sounds rather than a new murmur, which is a key manifestation of IE, and he does not have extracardiac manifestations of IE (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and Roth spots). Additionally, his ECG findings suggest another diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade, a complication of acute pericarditis, is caused by the combination of increased secretion of fluid into pericardial space and decreased elasticity of the pericardium secondary to inflammation. Once the pericardial effusion becomes sufficiently pronounced, either due to the rate of fluid accumulation or the amount of fluid, the heart can become compressed, which decreases cardiac output and ventricular diastolic filling. This patient presents with the classic symptoms of cardiac tamponade: hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds (i.e., Beck triad) as well as a characteristic ECG finding of low-voltage QRS complexes and fluctuating R wave amplitude (i.e., electrical alternans).
questions.hint: A 12-hour history of dyspnea and inspiratory chest pain in the setting of a 5-day prodrome of subjective fever, malaise, and dry cough suggests an acute infection of the pericardium.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of dyspnea and intermittent retrosternal chest pain that radiates to her back. She describes the pain as 6 out of 10 in intensity. One week ago, she could not go to work because of fever, runny nose, and a dry cough that lasted 3 days. She has hypertension well-controlled with ramipril. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her mother has a bicuspid aortic valve. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Complete blood count and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. Serum troponin T concentration is 0.02 ng/mL (N = 0–0.02), and serum creatine kinase concentration is 15 U/L. An ECG is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Pulmonary artery occlusion on CT angiography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A systolic ejection murmur on auscultation is a typical finding in aortic stenosis, which can manifest with chest pain and dyspnea. A family history of bicuspid aortic valve increases this patient's risk of having bicuspid aortic valve, which is a risk factor for aortic stenosis. However, in patients with aortic stenosis, symptoms typically develop more progressively, usually first manifesting with exertion. Moreover, ECG findings in aortic stenosis include signs of ventricular hypertrophy, not the diffuse ST elevations seen on this patient's ECG.

B) INCORRECT:

A lobar consolidation on chest x-ray is a typical finding of lobar pneumonia, which manifests with chest pain and dyspnea. However, the lung auscultation usually reveals crackles and/or bronchial breath sounds, while this patient's lungs are clear to auscultation. Other features of typical pneumonia include fever, chills, and a productive cough, none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, pneumonia does not cause diffuse ST elevations on ECG.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary artery occlusion on CT angiography confirms pulmonary embolism (PE), which manifests with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea. This patient's smoking history also increases the risk of developing PE. However, she has no signs or symptoms suggestive of deep venous thrombosis, history of prior venous thromboembolism, surgery/immobilization, hemoptysis, or malignancy. Therefore, her Wells score is zero, and a CT angiography is not indicated. Moreover, ECG findings in PE include sinus tachycardia, S1Q3T3 pattern, new right bundle branch block, and right axis deviation, not the diffuse ST elevations seen on this patient's ECG.
Image Description:

12 channel ECG with sinus rhythm, negative T-wave in V1-V5, and S1Q3T3 pattern (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III and negative T-wave in lead III).

Findings of a negative T-wave in the anterior leads and an S1Q3T3 pattern suggest an acute pulmonary embolism.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's acute chest pain and dyspnea in combination with the ECG findings are suggestive of acute pericarditis. This condition is most commonly caused by a viral infection, indicated by the fever, runny nose, and dry cough this patient had 1 week ago. Acute pericarditis typically manifests with acute sharp retrosternal pain that is exacerbated by inspiration and coughing and improves with sitting and leaning forward. However, patients may present with atypical chest pain, as seen in this case. For the diagnosis of acute pericarditis, at least two of the following four criteria must be present: a characteristic chest pain (pleuritic), a pericardial friction rub, typical ECG changes (diffuse, concave-upward ST segment elevations), and new or worsening pericardial effusion on echocardiography. A pericardial high-pitched friction rub on auscultation is present in 85% of patients with acute pericarditis and, in combination with this patient's ECG findings, would confirm the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A valvular vegetation on echocardiography is one of the major Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with chest pain and dyspnea. However, confirming the diagnosis of IE requires the presence of at least one other major criterion (e.g., two positive blood cultures for typical pathogens) or at least three of the minor criteria (underlying heart disease or intravenous drug use, fever, vascular phenomena, immunologic phenomena, positive blood cultures that do not fulfill major criteria), all of which are absent in this patient. Moreover, infective endocarditis would not explain this patient's ECG findings.

F) INCORRECT:

Vessel occlusion on coronary angiography indicates myocardial infarction, which manifests with acute retrosternal chest pain and dyspnea. However, in myocardial infarction, the chest pain is usually persistent rather than intermittent; the pain is commonly described as a dull, squeezing pressure or tightness. Additionally, ECG findings include ST elevation in anatomically contiguous leads that correspond to the infarcted area, not the diffuse ST elevations seen here. Moreover, troponin T would be increased in patients with myocardial infarction.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 83/min
- Normal cardiac axis: R > S in leads I and aVF
- Normal QRS complex
- ST elevation in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF; blue overlay) with reciprocal ST depression in aVL (red overlay) and pathological Q waves in III (example indicated by green circle overlay)
questions.hint: The 12-lead ECG shows diffuse, concave, upward-sloping ST segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V3–V6, with reciprocal ST depression in aVR and V1.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of sharp retrosternal chest pain that radiates to the neck and worsens on inspiration. Last night, he had difficulty sleeping because lying down exacerbated the pain. He was on sick leave last week because of a sore throat and a nonproductive cough. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Cardiac auscultation discloses a regular rate and rhythm and a high-pitched squeaking sound over the left sternal border; no murmurs are heard. There is no jugular vein distention. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Complete blood count and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. Serum troponin I concentration is 0.04 ng/mL and creatine kinase activity is 20 U/L. ECG is shown. Echocardiography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography is the most definitive diagnostic test for pulmonary embolism (PE), which manifests with acute, pleuritic chest pain, fever, and dyspnea, all of which are seen here. However, this patient has no features of deep vein thrombosis, a history of prior venous thromboembolism, surgery/immobilization, hemoptysis, or malignancy. Therefore, the Wells score for this patient is zero, and CT angiography is not indicated. Moreover, ECG findings in PE include sinus tachycardia, SIQIIITIII pattern, new right bundle branch block, and right axis deviation, but not diffuse ST elevations, which are seen on this patient's ECG.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Normal rate (approx. 90/min)
– Cardiac axis ∼ 90° (QRS complex is isoelectric in I and positive in aVF): borderline normal/right-axis deviation
– P pulmonale: P-wave amplitude ≥ 0.25 mV in II, III, and aVF
– PR interval normal (< 0.2 s)
– QRS duration 0.1–0.12 s (incomplete bundle branch block)
– QTc interval normal (∼ 0.4 s)
– Discordant T-wave inversion in III, aVR, V1, V3–V6
– SIQIIITIII-pattern: deep S waves in I (blue overlay), pathological Q waves in III (green overlay), and T-wave inversion in III (red overlay)

The SIQIIITIII-pattern and P pulmonale are both suggestive of pulmonary embolism, but neither of these findings is sensitive or specific for this diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Antiinflammatory therapy to control pain and prevent recurrence is the mainstay of management in patients with acute pericarditis because this condition is most often self-limited. While NSAID therapy (e.g., with ibuprofen) usually provides symptomatic relief, it is often used in combination with colchicine, which improves response to therapy and reduces recurrence rates. In patients with nonviral underlying causes (e.g., bacterial, autoimmune, uremic), specific therapy is also indicated; this patient's history of recent upper respiratory tract infection suggests a viral etiology and, therefore, no other specific treatment is needed. Patients should restrict physical activity until symptoms have resolved and C-reactive protein has normalized; for athletes, ECG and echocardiogram findings should also be normal before training is resumed.

Treatment with glucocorticoids may also be considered in patients with contraindications to NSAIDs and patients in whom treatment with NSAIDs and colchicine has been unsuccessful. Glucocorticoid treatment is also indicated in patients with pericarditis resulting from autoimmune disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are an essential diagnostic test in patients with infective endocarditis (IE), which typically manifests with fever and pleuritic chest pain, similar to what is seen here. However, additional symptoms are expected, such as a new heart murmur and the development of extracardiac symptoms (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Osler nodes, Roth spots, Janeway lesions), none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, in IE, echocardiography typically shows vegetation; this patient's echocardiogram shows no abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray is indicated for all patients with suspected pneumonia, which manifests with fever, pleuritic chest pain, and dyspnea, similar to what is seen here. Auscultation findings in pneumonia include crackles and bronchial breath sounds, whereas this patient's lungs are clear to auscultation. In patients with acute pericarditis, a chest x-ray can be performed to exclude other diagnoses (e.g., pulmonary infection, malignancy) and assess for complications (e.g., large pericardial effusions). Since this patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for pericarditis and echocardiography shows no pericardial effusion, a chest x-ray is of little diagnostic value.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with acute pericarditis, like this one, pericardiocentesis is used either as a diagnostic test (if purulent or malignant pericarditis is suspected) or as a therapeutic procedure (in concomitant large pericardial effusions or cardiac tamponade). This patient's acute pericarditis, however, most likely has a viral etiology and echocardiography shows no pericardial effusions; therefore, pericardiocentesis is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel is indicated for patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which manifests with acute retrosternal chest pain and dyspnea, both of which are seen here. Chest pain in ACS is usually described as a dull, squeezing pressure or tightness. This patient's chest pain, however, is pleuritic. Additionally, ECG findings include ST elevation in anatomically contiguous leads that correspond to the infarcted area rather than diffuse ST elevations, which this patient has. Moreover, troponin I and creatinine kinase activity are increased in ACS.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 83/min
- Normal cardiac axis: R > S in leads I and aVF
- Normal QRS complex
- ST elevation in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF; blue overlay) with reciprocal ST depression in aVL (red overlay) and pathological Q waves in III (example indicated by green circle overlay)
questions.hint: ECG shows concave ST elevations in multiple leads (I, II, aVL, V2–V6) with ST depression in lead aVR. These findings suggest pericarditis. The diagnosis of acute pericarditis requires at least two of the following four criteria: characteristic chest pain (pleuritic), pericardial friction rub, typical ECG changes (diffuse, concave, upward-sloping ST segment elevations), and new or worsening pericardial effusion on echocardiography. This patient meets the first three clinical criteria.

questions.text: Three days after undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting for coronary artery disease, a 62-year-old man develops retrosternal chest pain. He has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include enalapril, simvastatin, and metformin. The patient appears to be in acute distress. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.9°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 105/74 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows muffled heart sounds. There is a mildly tender midline sternotomy surgical wound with minimal erythema and no discharge. Hemoglobin concentration is 12.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 129 mm/h. An x-ray of the chest shows an increased cardiothoracic ratio. ECG shows diffuse ST elevations. Transthoracic echocardiography shows moderate pericardial effusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Wound opening and cleaning with saline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chest CT can be used to diagnose mediastinitis, which is a complication of cardiothoracic surgery and manifests with retrosternal chest pain, fever, signs of shock, and in some cases, pericarditis. However, this complication is also associated with dysphagia, subcutaneous emphysema, and superior vena cava syndrome, none of which is seen in this patient. This patient's ECG findings, elevated inflammatory markers, and features of pericardial effusion are more suggestive of purulent pericarditis, which requires another management strategy.

B) CORRECT:

Purulent pericarditis most commonly develops after thoracic surgery or cardiac injury and is typically caused by Staphylococcus spp., Streptococcus spp., or (where it is endemic) Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The diagnosis is typically confirmed based on the presence of purulent exudate in the pericardial sac on echocardiography. Immediate management consists of pericardiocentesis to rapidly resolve pericardial effusion and/or cardiac tamponade. Subsequently, pericardial fluid and blood cultures should be conducted, followed by empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy (e.g., vancomycin, ceftriaxone, or meropenem), then targeted antibiotic therapy based on culture results. Surgical drainage or intrapericardial fibrinolysis may be necessary if there is loculation.
Image Description:

Echocardiography transthoracic (apical view; A: without needle; B and C: with needle)

Anechoic pericardial effusion (PE) was identified. Needle position (arrows) was continuously monitored while the pericardial space was entered to drain the effusion.

Arrowheads: myocardium

C) INCORRECT:

Wound opening and irrigation with saline are indicated for surgical wound infections, which can manifest postoperatively with retrosternal chest pain, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers. However, in the case of surgical wound infection, purulent discharge would be seen draining from the surgical site, whereas this patient has a dry surgical wound.

D) INCORRECT:

Coronary angiography is used to evaluate the extent of coronary artery disease (CAD), which also manifests with retrosternal chest pain and ST elevations. Although this patient has recently undergone coronary artery bypass grafting for CAD, his history of recent surgery, elevated inflammatory markers, and features of pericardial effusion are more suggestive of purulent pericarditis, which requires another management strategy.

E) INCORRECT:

Viral pericarditis, which is treated with glucocorticoids and colchicine, is the most common type of pericarditis and typically manifests with acute pleuritic chest pain and, in some cases, pericardial effusion. However, viral pericarditis is most commonly caused by pericardial inflammation due to the coxsackie B virus and is typically preceded by flu-like symptoms. This patient's history of recent thoracic surgery makes purulent pericarditis more likely, which requires another management strategy.
questions.hint: In a patient with chest pain and fever who has recently undergone cardiac surgery, fever, elevated inflammatory markers, diffuse ST elevations, an increased cardiothoracic ratio, and the presence of pericardial effusion on echocardiography should raise concern for purulent pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is hospitalized with weight gain, worsening lower-extremity edema, and increasing abdominal girth. His symptoms have progressed despite initiation of diuretic therapy 3 months ago. He was treated with chest radiation and chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma at age 21.
On physical examination, he is afebrile and has a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 120/70 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while breathing ambient air. His jugular venous pressure is elevated and increases with inspiration, but cardiac and pulmonary examinations are otherwise unremarkable. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the costal margin, and he has 3+ pitting edema of the lower extremities.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a normal serum creatinine level, mildly elevated liver aminotransferase levels, and a total bilirubin concentration of 2.0 mg/dL (reference range, 0.3–1.0).
An abdominal ultrasound shows liver enlargement without obvious cirrhosis, as well as moderate ascites.
A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals normal left ventricular systolic function, with abnormal septal motion and a dilated inferior vena cava, without inspiratory collapse. During respiration, flow velocities across the tricuspid and mitral valves fluctuate substantially.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sildenafil is indicated for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

A transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt can help to alleviate recurrent ascites related to portal hypertension from cirrhosis, but it has no place in treating constrictive pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical septal myectomy is indicated for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy when symptoms are refractory to medical management, not for constrictive pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol is indicated for patients with heart failure that is due to left ventricular systolic dysfunction.

E) CORRECT:

Peripheral venous congestion (elevated jugular venous pressure, anasarca, ascites, hepatic congestion) in the absence of pulmonary venous congestion in a patient with a history of chest irradiation is consistent with a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis. Common causes of this condition include tuberculosis, previous cardiac surgery, acute pericarditis, autoimmune disease, and previous chest irradiation.

Physical examination findings in patients with constrictive pericarditis include Kussmaul sign (lack of decline or increased jugular venous distention with inspiration), pulsus paradoxus, and, less commonly, an audible pericardial friction rub or knock. A chest radiograph may reveal rimmed calcification around the heart, best seen on a lateral view of the chest. Echocardiographic findings include abnormal septal “bounce,” resulting from respiratory variation of septal motion, exaggerated respiratory variation in tricuspid and mitral inflow velocities, and a dilated inferior vena cava with minimal inspiratory collapse.

Pericardiectomy is the treatment of choice in a patient with chronic symptoms attributable to constrictive pericarditis that is refractory to conservative management (e.g., diuretics). Surgery should not be delayed in patients with constrictive pericarditis because advanced heart failure is associated with a high rate of operative mortality.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with ascites, lower-extremity edema, and Kussmaul sign who underwent chest irradiation at age 21 is constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man with no risk factors for tuberculosis presents with fever, pleuritic chest pain, and mild dyspnea. He is found to have a large pericardial effusion.
His erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 45 mm/hr (reference range, 0–17). Blood cultures and serologic screening for autoimmune conditions are negative.
One liter of serosanguineous fluid is drained with pericardiocentesis; fluid analysis reveals a leukocyte count of 2000 per mm3, with 90% lymphocytes.
Which one of the following first-line therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Several studies have shown that the use of glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, in acute pericarditis can increase the risk for recurrence. Consequently, glucocorticoid use should generally be restricted to patients with severely symptomatic recurrent pericarditis who are unresponsive to initial therapy with the pharmacotherapy of choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine may be used as a glucocorticoid-sparing therapy in cases of severe recurrent pericarditis, but the published literature on this agent is scant.

C) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate may be used as a glucocorticoid-sparing therapy in cases of severe recurrent pericarditis, but the published literature on this agent is scant.

D) INCORRECT:

Data on intrapericardial delivery of triamcinolone in patients with acute pericarditis are limited. Although this approach has been successful in a small number of patients, it is not an established management option.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with a first episode of acute pericarditis. Tuberculous pericarditis is a possible alternative diagnosis, but in the absence of risk factors for tuberculosis, the patient can be treated for acute pericarditis. Initial treatment is with a combination of aspirin and colchicine, which markedly speeds symptomatic recovery and helps to prevent recurrence.

Key learning point: In a patient with a first episode of acute pericarditis, the best treatment for speeding recovery and reducing the risk for recurrence is aspirin and colchicine.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman with a history of intravenous heroin use is admitted to the intensive care unit. For one week, she has been experiencing fevers, rigors, lethargy, confusion, and a cough productive of green sputum. She is hypoxemic, and a chest radiograph reveals multilobar consolidation. She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Antibiotics are started for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia.
Shortly after admission, the patient reports sharp, constant chest pain that worsens when she lies down or takes a deep breath and that lessens when she leans forward. She has a temperature of 39.9°C, a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 148/88 mm Hg; her systolic blood pressure falls by 8 mm Hg during inspiration. Her oxygen saturation is 93% with a face mask delivering a 60% fraction of inspired oxygen.
Her examination is notable for disorientation to place and time, diaphoresis, and widespread coarse inspiratory crackles. Jugular veins are not visible when the patient is sitting upright. A high-pitched, scratchy sound is intermittently audible upon auscultation at the left sternal border and persists when the patient holds her breath. She has warm extremities without edema.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chest pain typical of pericarditis has sudden onset, is retrosternal, and is relieved by leaning forward; it may radiate to the trapezius ridge. A pericardial friction rub, audible in about 85% of patients with acute pericarditis, is a high-pitched scratchy sound best appreciated at the left sternal border at end expiration as the patient leans forward.

Key learning point: The mostly likely cause of sharp chest pain that is exacerbated by inspiration or a supine posture and is accompanied by a high-pitched, scratchy sound that is intermittently audible at the left sternal border independent of the respiratory cycle is acute pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

The absence of hypotension, pulsus paradoxus (an exaggerated fall in systolic blood pressure during inspiration) >10 mm Hg, and jugular venous distention excludes cardiac tamponade.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism can cause sharp chest pain and a pleural friction rub (that is absent when the patient holds his or her breath) but not a pericardial friction rub.

D) INCORRECT:

The classic tearing pain of aortic dissection radiates to the back.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute pulmonary valve insufficiency is characterized by features of right heart failure but not by positional chest pain.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus reports an 8-hour history of retrosternal chest discomfort. Her pain is dull in character, radiates to both her scapulae, and is not associated with exertion. The discomfort is relieved when she sits upright and worsens when she lies down.
She is afebrile. Her heart rate is 65 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 105/72 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 98% while she is breathing ambient air. Her cardiac examination is notable for a pericardial friction rub; her pulmonary examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a serum creatine kinase-MB concentration of 1 ng/mL (reference range, 0–7) and a troponin-T level (measured using a 4th-generation assay) of 0.02 ng/mL (0–0.03).
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The typical electrocardiographic (ECG) changes in patients with acute pericarditis are diffuse, concave ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression. Four stages of ECG abnormalities have been described:

• Stage 1: diffuse ST-segment elevation secondary to epicardial inflammation (with reciprocal ST-segment depression in leads aVR and V1) and PR-segment depression
• Stage 2: normalization of the ST and PR segments
• Stage 3: development of widespread T-wave inversion
• Stage 4: ECG normalization or indefinite persistence of T-wave inversion

Pericardial friction rub is present in 35% to 85% of patients with acute pericarditis and is very specific for this condition.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a woman with positional chest pain who is found to have diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression on electrocardiogram is acute pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

The most common ECG feature of pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia. The findings in this patient are not consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common ECG findings in patients with myocarditis are diffuse T-wave inversions and saddle-shaped ST-segment elevations.

D) INCORRECT:

Myocardial infarction involving the atrial myocardium is rare, but it can manifest with PR-segment depression; however, infarction is typically accompanied by elevated cardiac enzymes. This patient’s features are more typical of pericarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

The Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome manifests as a short PR interval and is associated with preexcitation (a delta wave in the QRS segment). Typical feature includes palpitations or presyncope/syncope.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old male former smoker with hypertension and coronary artery disease reports a 4-week history of worsening dyspnea on exertion, increasing abdominal girth, and lower-extremity edema. He has no chest pain. Three years ago, he underwent 3-vessel coronary artery bypass surgery. He currently takes aspirin, lovastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril.
On examination, the patient has a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 100/50 mm Hg, and a pulsus paradoxus of 12 mm Hg. He now weighs approximately 20 pounds more than he did at his last office visit. He is in mild respiratory distress at rest without cyanosis. He has elevated jugular venous pressure, which increases with inspiration.
Cardiovascular examination reveals normal first and second heart sounds, followed by a third heart sound and a soft pericardial knock. The patient also has an abdominal fluid wave, a tender liver edge 2 cm below the right costal margin, and 4+ pedal edema.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
143
136–145



Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.2
3.5–5.0


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
22
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.1
0.8–1.3


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
120
0–35


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
145
0–35


A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is characterized by hepatic and renal dysfunction, as well as low voltage and conduction abnormalities on electrocardiogram.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade manifests as tachycardia with hypotension, elevated jugular venous pressure, and distant heart sounds with a pulsus paradoxus >10 mm Hg on inspiration.

C) INCORRECT:

A patient with ventricular septal rupture becomes acutely ill and would have a holosystolic murmur related to shunting across the defect.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with findings of significant heart failure (anasarca, hepatic congestion with mild abnormalities on liver function testing), the presence of a soft pericardial knock and Kussmaul sign on physical examination is suggestive of constrictive pericarditis. A chest radiograph in patients with constrictive pericarditis often reveals pericardial calcifications. Chronic inflammation of the pericardium causes thickening and calcification with loss of elasticity, which can lead to constrictive pericarditis. Open-heart surgery, one of many possible causes of pericardial inflammation, can lead to smoldering pericarditis that eventually becomes constrictive. When the pericardium is constrictive, it does not expand to accommodate increases in venous return, and ventricular volumes are reduced; this results in fluid overload and symptoms of reduced cardiac output, such as dyspnea on exertion. A pericardial knock is an accentuated heart sound heard in early diastole in patients with constrictive pericarditis; it is caused by the abrupt cessation of diastolic filling of the ventricles. Kussmaul sign (a lack of decline in jugular venous pressure with inspiration) is sometimes evident in these patients, but it is less specific, as it is a characteristic of right-sided heart failure and severe tricuspid insufficiency.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of peripheral venous congestion in a patient who has a history of cardiac surgery is constrictive pericarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

No inciting factors (e.g., previous alcohol use) are present to suggest a diagnosis of cryptogenic cirrhosis, nor do mild abnormalities in liver function or a tender liver edge 2 cm below the right costal margin suggest this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman reports progressive shortness of breath for the past 6 months. She moved from West Africa to the United States 2 years ago. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive pill.
On presentation, she is afebrile, with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 120/70 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Her jugular venous pressure is 10 cm above the sternal border while she is reclining at a 45-degree angle, and it increases with inspiration. Breath sounds are normal bilaterally, and a loud heart sound is audible immediately after S2 . She has a distended abdomen with a fluid wave and bilateral pedal edema.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic mitral stenosis is associated with a low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur and symptoms of pulmonary venous congestion (i.e., pulmonary edema).

B) INCORRECT:

Viral myocarditis is usually associated with acute-onset heart failure symptoms. A viral prodrome would suggest a diagnosis of viral myocarditis.

C) CORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is the result of a chronic inflammatory process that leads to pericardial thickening and subsequent constriction of the cardiac chambers, with impaired diastolic filling and venous congestion.

Although not common in industrialized countries, tuberculosis is the leading cause of constrictive pericarditis worldwide. When tuberculosis infection spreads to the pericardium, it initially causes a suppurative exudate that eventually leads to pericardial thickening and calcification. Affected patients often present with symptoms and signs of peripheral venous congestion, including elevated jugular venous pressure, ascites, pedal edema, and shortness of breath. A pericardial knock may be audible immediately after S2 ; it is caused by abrupt cessation of diastolic filling of the ventricles. A chest radiograph may reveal pericardial calcification, although CT and MRI are more sensitive than radiography for detecting pericardial thickening and calcification.

Key learning point: Elevated jugular venous pressure with Kussmaul sign (increase in jugular venous pressure with inspiration), ascites, lower-extremity edema, and a pericardial knock are classic findings in a patient with constrictive pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Although arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia (i.e., replacement of the ventricular myocardium with fibrofatty tissue) may yield signs and symptoms of right ventricular failure, it is frequently associated with ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death in children and young adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Endomyocardial fibrosis, a disease predominantly seen in West Africans, may lead to a restrictive cardiomyopathy. Although symptoms and signs of peripheral venous congestion are seen with both restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis, calcification of the pericardium is seen only with the latter.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man reports a one-week history of retrosternal chest pain that radiates to his neck and back. The pain developed 3 weeks after an upper respiratory infection resolved and is not accompanied by lightheadedness, dizziness, or diaphoresis. The patient reports that the pain is worse when he is lying down and relieved when he sits upright; it does not change with oral intake.
His vital signs are unremarkable. He has normal first and second heart sounds and a systolic rub, best appreciated when he leans forward. His electrocardiogram reveals normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific T-wave changes.
Which one of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In an individual with acute viral pericarditis, the addition of moderate-dose colchicine to a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen, results in significantly better rates of remission and recurrence than treatment with an nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug alone. Thus, both drugs are recommended in patients with acute viral pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

C) CORRECT:

In an individual with acute viral pericarditis, the addition of moderate-dose colchicine to a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen, results in significantly better rates of remission and recurrence than treatment with an nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug alone. Thus, both drugs are recommended in patients with acute viral pericarditis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management of acute viral pericarditis involves a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug and colchicine.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

Although most cases of acute pericarditis are attributed to a viral etiology, antiinfluenza therapy, such as oseltamivir, has not been shown to effectively treat acute pericarditis or prevent its recurrence.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old woman reports 3 months of fatigue, vague abdominal discomfort, and an 11-kg weight gain associated with marked abdominal distention. She denies orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. She underwent coronary-artery bypass grafting 15 years ago and aortic valve replacement (with a bioprosthetic valve) one year ago. Her left ventricular systolic function was normal after valve replacement.
On examination, she has a blood pressure of 112/76 mm Hg, a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. Her sclerae are mildly icteric. Her jugular venous pressure is 18 cm of water. Her lungs are clear. She has a normal first and second heart sound. A grade 2/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur is audible in the aortic area, and a high-pitched, early diastolic heart sound is audible at the apex. No rub is appreciated. She has a distended abdomen and evidence of ascites. Her extremities are warm, with 1+ bilateral pitting edema.
A chest radiograph shows no cardiomegaly or signs of pulmonary venous congestion.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s signs and symptoms?

choices.text: Malfunction of the aortic valve bioprosthesis
Congestive heart failure with left ventricular systolic dysfunction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The aortic flow murmur is consistent with a normally functioning bioprosthetic aortic valve. Valve dysfunction would cause symptoms of left heart failure, which are not present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Although cirrhosis can cause lower-extremity edema, it does not cause elevated jugular venous pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

Although nephrotic syndrome can cause lower-extremity edema, it does not cause elevated jugular venous pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

At first glance, the patient’s presentation could be consistent with right ventricular failure secondary to left ventricular failure. However, she has no evidence of left ventricular failure.

E) CORRECT:

This patient reports fatigue, abdominal distention, and weight gain, and on examination, she has elevated jugular venous pressure, icterus, ascites, and bilateral lower-extremity edema. These findings — in conjunction with her high-pitched, early diastolic heart sound (pericardial knock), tachycardia, and history of two previous cardiac surgeries — are consistent with a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis, leading to elevated systemic venous pressure. The icterus and ascites are due to hepatic congestion and dysfunction (congestive hepatopathy) related to the elevated systemic venous pressure.

The aortic flow murmur is consistent with a normally functioning bioprosthetic aortic valve. Valve dysfunction would cause symptoms of left heart failure, which are not present in this patient.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of high jugular venous pressure, ascites, and peripheral edema in a patient with normal left ventricular systolic function who has undergone multiple cardiac surgeries is constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man reports 7 days of constant, pleuritic anterior chest pain.
He has a current temperature of 37.6°C, a heart rate of 75 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 115/73 mm Hg. His respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 99% while he is breathing ambient air.
Physical examination identifies scratchy sounds at the lower left sternal border that are audible throughout the respiratory cycle and that occur in both systole and diastole. The duration of the sounds is similar to that of heart murmurs. The patient’s lungs are clear, and there is no jugular venous distention.
A 12-lead electrocardiogram shows diffuse T-wave inversions but no ST-segment changes.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although pulmonary embolism can cause pleuritic chest pain, the patient has no tachycardia or hypoxemia. Furthermore, the pleural friction rub associated with pulmonary embolism is audible only during active breathing (i.e., it is absent as the breath is held), in contrast with a pericardial friction rub, which is audible throughout the respiratory cycle.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade is a possible consequence of pericarditis if the latter is accompanied by an effusion. However, the patient’s vital signs are normal, and he shows no signs of tamponade (e.g., jugular venous distention, pulsus paradoxus) on physical examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Prinzmetal angina causes intermittent — rather than 7 days of constant — chest pain, and any associated ECG changes would be localized rather than diffuse.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute coronary syndrome causes intermittent — rather than 7 days of constant — chest pain, and any associated ECG changes would be localized rather than diffuse.

E) CORRECT:

Acute pericarditis is defined by the presence of two of the following three features: pleuritic anterior chest pain, a pericardial friction rub (which is often scratchy in character), and characteristic electrocardiographic (ECG) changes consisting of widespread ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression. On physical examination, patients will often have improvement or relief of their pain when leaning forward.

In the absence of treatment, the ECG changes may progress through four stages:

• Stage 1: diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression
• Stage 2: normalization of the ST and PR segments, often with T-wave flattening
• Stage 3: widespread T-wave inversions
• Stage 4: normalization of T waves

Stage 1 typically occurs in the first hours to days, stage 2 within several days, and stages 3 and 4 within days to weeks. This patient has had chest pain for 7 days, and his ECG changes are in stage 3.

Key learning point: Early acute pericarditis is typically associated with electrocardiographic changes of ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression, but in the absence of treatment, the ST and PR segments may normalize and T-wave flattening or inversions may develop.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man reports several hours of left-sided chest and shoulder pain 2 days after receiving a drug-eluting coronary stent for an acute anterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. His door-to-balloon time was 4 hours. Lying down and taking a deep breath exacerbates his chest pain.
On examination, his temperature is 38.2°C, his heart rate is 90 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and his respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. His breath sounds are normal. He has new scratchy systolic and diastolic auscultatory findings at the left lower sternal border.
A 12-lead electrocardiogram reveals anterior Q waves and diffuse ST-segment elevations.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute stent thrombosis is not associated with fever, pleuritic chest pain, or these auscultatory findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Although papillary muscle rupture or ventricular septal rupture can occur within a few days after acute MI, the patient usually experiences acute pulmonary vascular congestion and hemodynamic instability. In addition, these complications produce systolic but not diastolic murmurs.

C) CORRECT:

Pleuritic chest pain, fever, and scratchy systolic and diastolic auscultatory findings (consistent with pericardial rub) that develop 2 days after a myocardial infarction (MI) are most consistent with a diagnosis of post-MI pericarditis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with pleuritic chest pain, fever, new scratchy systolic and diastolic auscultatory findings, and new ST-segment elevations within a few days after an acute myocardial infarction is pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

In-stent restenosis does not occur within days after stent placement.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism might cause pleuritic pain but would not cause a pericardial friction rub or these electrocardiographic abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and dyspnea.
Her symptoms began suddenly 3 days ago and have been getting progressively worse, such that she can no longer climb a flight of stairs comfortably. The chest pain, which she rates as an 8 out of 10 in intensity, is left-sided and radiates to her neck. It worsens with deep inspiration and when she lies flat on her back. She describes having low-grade fevers, rhinorrhea, and a cough approximately 7 days ago, a faint malar rash one day ago, and increased myalgias.
She has no history of blood clots or miscarriages, no recent travel, and no sick contacts. Her only medication is hydroxychloroquine 400 mg once daily.
Her vital signs include a temperature of 38.5°C, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 132/70 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while she is breathing ambient air.
Given this patient’s history of systemic lupus erythematosus and her current presentation, what physical examination finding is most likely?

choices.text: Bronchial breath sounds at the left lower lobe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism is an important consideration in an SLE patient with acute pleuritic chest pain and/or dyspnea, but in this case, the absence of tachycardia or hypoxemia and the positional nature of the pain argue against pulmonary embolism and in favor of pericarditis. Consequently, asymmetric calf swelling as a sign of deep venous thrombosis would be unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The positional chest pain features are not typical of pneumonia, which might be associated with bronchial breath sounds.

C) INCORRECT:

Lower-extremity edema can be seen in patients with constrictive pericarditis, but constrictive pericarditis is rare in SLE, particularly without a history of repeated episodes of pericardial inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus would be a sign of cardiac tamponade, which can result from pericarditis, but large effusions causing tamponade physiology are unusual in patients with SLE.

E) CORRECT:

The combination of dyspnea and sudden-onset positional chest pain in the setting of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is suggestive of pericarditis. Small pericardial effusions and pericarditis are common in patients with SLE and often coincide with other evidence of active SLE flare. On physical examination, a pericardial friction rub is highly specific for pericarditis, although sensitivity is low.

Key learning point: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, the most common cause of symptomatic cardiac disease is pericardial involvement, notably small pericardial effusions and pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man with a history of hypertension reports 3 days of retrosternal chest pain that becomes worse with inspiration. He says the pain bothers him most when he is trying to sleep and that it improves when he sits up. His home medications include chlorthalidone.
He has a temperature of 37.3°C, a blood pressure of 121/75 mm Hg, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. His lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals a high-pitched squeak in systole as well as in diastole that is best heard at the left lower sternal border. His jugular venous pressure is normal. He has no lower-extremity edema.
An electrocardiogram reveals nonspecific, diffuse ST/T-wave changes.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exercise stress testing and cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography can better elucidate the cause of exercise-related dyspnea or chest pain, but this patient does not report dyspnea, and his chest pain is not noted to occur during exertion.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI can be helpful in the evaluation of suspected myocardial disease but is not usually part of the evaluation for acute pericarditis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and examination findings are consistent with acute pericarditis. Pericardial chest pain is typically positional (worse when supine, better when leaning forward) and pleuritic (worse with inspiration), and these features distinguish it from the pain associated with myocardial ischemia. A pericardial rub, as heard in this case, classically has three audible components: atrial systole, ventricular systole, and rapid ventricular filling during early diastole.

Although classic electrocardiographic findings of pericarditis include diffuse, concave ST-segment elevations and PR-segment depressions, these are often not present. An echocardiogram is the preferred initial noninvasive imaging test for acute pericarditis, to evaluate for pericardial effusion; it can also help detect tamponade physiology in unstable patients.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step to further evaluate a patient with pleuritic chest pain, a pericardial rub, and nonspecific electrocardiographic findings is echocardiography to assess for pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography would be appropriate if pulmonary embolism (PE) were suspected. Although pleuritic chest pain is a common presenting feature of PE, this patient reports no dyspnea or risk factors for PE, and his physical examination findings (including the pericardial rub, lack of lower-extremity edema, and absence of tachycardia) are not consistent with that diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Exercise stress testing and cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography can better elucidate the cause of exercise-related dyspnea or chest pain, but this patient does not report dyspnea, and his chest pain is not noted to occur during exertion.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old man with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, now with stage 5 chronic kidney disease, has been experiencing pleuritic chest pain for the past week. The chest pain is positional, improved with sitting forward and worsened with lying flat. The patient reports that his appetite has been normal, and he has not experienced nausea or vomiting.
On physical examination, he is hemodynamically stable, with a blood pressure of 145/82 mm Hg and a temperature of 38.1°C. He weighs 2.5 kg less than at his last visit. His lungs are clear, and there is no jugular venous distention. Scratchy systolic and diastolic sounds are heard along the left sternal border. There is trace to 1+ lower-extremity edema.
His blood urea nitrogen level is 96 mg/dL (reference range, 10–20), his serum creatinine level is 5.1 mg/dL (0.8–1.3), and his estimated glomerular filtration rate is 13 mL/min/1.73 m2 (≥60).
An electrocardiogram is normal, without any ST-T wave changes. Echocardiography shows a small pericardial effusion and normal function without wall-motion abnormalities.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute pericarditis from other causes (such as viral infection, Dressler syndrome, or autoimmune diseases) may respond to therapy directed at inflammation, such as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs, such as indomethacin) and colchicine. In this case, dialysis will be more effective. In addition, NSAIDs are generally not used in advanced chronic kidney disease because of the deleterious effect on remaining renal function.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute pericarditis from other causes (such as viral infection, Dressler syndrome, or autoimmune diseases) may respond to therapy directed at inflammation, such as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs, such as indomethacin) and colchicine. In this case, dialysis will be more effective. In addition, colchicine should be used sparingly because this agent is cleared by the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient is hemodynamically stable with a small effusion and no clinical findings suggestive of cardiac tamponade. Furthermore, the clinical diagnosis of uremic pericarditis is highly likely, and so therapeutic or diagnostic pericardiocentesis is unnecessary in this case.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s pleuritic positional chest pain, auscultatory findings of a pericardial friction rub, and fever are concerning for acute pericarditis. Given his advanced kidney failure, uremia is the likely cause. Most patients develop uremic symptoms when the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is <10 mL/min/1.73 m2,but some may develop symptoms at a higher eGFR; furthermore, this value is only an estimate of the actual renal function. This patient also has unexplained weight loss and may have mild uremic symptoms that have not been recognized.

Patients with uremic pericarditis may present with pain or be asymptomatic. In addition, they may not have the electrocardiographic changes that are commonly seen in other causes of acute pericarditis, such as diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression.

Patients with significant renal dysfunction and pericarditis should be treated with hemodialysis; if the patient is already undergoing dialysis, the regimen should be intensified. In most cases, intensive hemodialysis ameliorates the disorder.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with acute uremic pericarditis is hemodialysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid therapy is not advised for initial therapy of pericarditis and has been associated with recurrence. This strategy should be reserved for patients with connective tissue disorders that are refractory to other treatments.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 5-year-old boy presents with fever and malaise. He recently recovered from an upper respiratory infection but last night developed a tactile temperature and abdominal pain. This morning, his mother noted decreased appetite and a diminished activity level, prompting her to bring him in for evaluation. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On physical examination, he has a temperature of 39.8°C, a heart rate of 170 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 100/65 mm Hg. He appears nontoxic but uncomfortable. When asked to take a deep breath, he reports chest pain and repositions himself so that he is sitting up and leaning forward. On auscultation, a high-pitched scratching sound is heard along the left fourth intercostal space without any other murmurs. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and he has no hepatosplenomegaly.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to confirm the correct diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The presence of chest pain and a pericardial friction rub should raise suspicion for acute pericarditis. Viral infections (particularly coxsackie virus, adenovirus, influenza virus, and Epstein-Barr virus) are the most common causes of pericarditis in children, but bacterial infections and noninfectious conditions (rheumatologic, endocrine, and oncologic) may also be responsible.

Acute pericarditis is typically characterized by chest pain that radiates to the left shoulder, is worse with inspiration and supine positioning, and is relieved with upright positioning and sitting forward. Nonspecific findings include abdominal pain, cough, dyspnea, vomiting, and fever. A pericardial friction rub (which is often scratchy in character) is pathognomonic for pericarditis. Cardiac tamponade may also occur and may be characterized by muffled heart sounds and pulsus paradoxus (a decrease in systolic blood pressure with inspiration).

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of acute pericarditis. During the initial stages of disease, ECG changes include diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression. As the disease progresses, the ST and PR segments return to baseline, and the T waves start to flatten and then invert. These inversions may be permanent or may normalize later in the disease.

Key learning point: The most useful diagnostic test in a patient with suspected pericarditis is an electrocardiogram.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary embolism, but this patient has no risk factors for thrombosis, and his friction rub is pathognomonic for acute pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph is not typically necessary unless the patient has other concerning hemodynamic disturbances or examination findings. Similarly, a chest radiograph may show a “water bottle” heart (a sign of a moderate-to-large pericardial effusion), or it may be normal.

D) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram may reveal a pericardial effusion, but the absence of an effusion does not rule out pericarditis. Patients who present with pericarditis following cardiac surgery should generally have an echocardiogram to rule out a large pericardial effusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Troponin testing is used in patients with chest pain, but myocardial ischemia is uncommon in children with no underlying cardiac disease.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents with 3 days of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain. He says that the pain is worse when he lies flat or takes a deep breath. Two weeks ago, he had a cold — with fevers, myalgias, fatigue, and respiratory congestion — that has since resolved. He received his third Covid-19 vaccination 3 months ago, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On examination, he appears to be anxious and is clutching his chest. He has an elevated jugular venous pressure, bilateral pulmonary rales, and a heart rate of 112 beats per minute. He is mildly dyspneic at rest but becomes very short of breath with minimal exertion.
An electrocardiogram and chest radiograph are obtained (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Anomalous left coronary artery from the right coronary sinus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patient presenting with symptoms of an anomalous left coronary artery from the right coronary sinus typically has a history of crushing chest pain during intense physical activity, such as sprinting, and an ECG that shows Q waves in leads I and aVL.

B) INCORRECT:

The pain associated with costochondritis is typically reproducible with palpation over the costosternal junctions on physical examination and would not be associated with changes on chest radiograph or ECG.

C) INCORRECT:

Cocaine ingestion would be more likely to produce regional ST-segment changes (evident on ECG) related to myocardial ischemia from coronary spasm, rather than diffuse ST-segment changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Community-acquired pneumonia related to Streptococcus pneumoniae infection may manifest with chest pain and dyspnea; however, this patient’s findings on chest radiograph and physical examination are more consistent with congestive heart failure.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms of congestive heart failure related to viral perimyocarditis, as evident from his recent viral prodrome, rales on physical examination, findings on chest radiograph, and diffuse ST-segment elevation on electrocardiogram (ECG). In developed countries, 80% to 90% of perimyocarditis cases are idiopathic and presumed to be viral. Approximately 20 viruses have been implicated, including adenoviruses, parvovirus B19, human herpesvirus 6, and enteroviruses (including coxsackie virus). Recently, SARS-CoV-2 has been recognized as a cause of perimyocarditis, and in rare cases (particularly in teenagers and young adults), the Covid-19 mRNA vaccines can cause a self-limited perimyocarditis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent who presents with acute positional chest pain, exertional dyspnea, a recent viral illness, diffuse ST-segment elevation on electrocardiogram, and pulmonary vascular congestion on chest radiograph is viral perimyocarditis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 15-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of sharp, left-sided, nonradiating chest pain that worsens with inspiration and lying down — and improves with sitting up and leaning forward. The patient also reports difficulty breathing and catching her breath. She recently traveled by air from San Francisco to New York and developed flulike symptoms (fever, rhinorrhea, and cough) around that time. She is up to date on her vaccines, including Covid-19 vaccination, having received her third dose 2 months ago. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
Physical examination reveals a heart rate of 116 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while the patient breathes ambient air. Her breath sounds are difficult to auscultate because her pain is causing her to take shallow breaths. She has a normal first heart sound, a split second heart sound, a 2/6 vibratory systolic murmur heard at the left midsternal border, and a rub. Her chest pain is not reproducible with palpation over costochondral junctions. She has no hepatomegaly or peripheral edema.
A chest radiograph is normal. An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following medications is most important to initiate in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids may be considered when the affected patient has a contraindication to NSAID use, such as renal insufficiency. Given that these drugs may boost viral replication and increase the recurrence of viral pericarditis, they are not used as first-line therapy for acute viral pericarditis. There is also some evidence that patients with pericarditis treated with glucocorticoids have increased risk of recurrence.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s constellation of symptoms and diffuse ST-segment elevations on electrocardiogram are consistent with acute pericarditis, most likely caused by a virus, given her recent flulike illness. The viruses that most often lead to pericarditis are adenovirus, coxsackie A and B viruses, and echovirus.

Patients with pericarditis typically present with chest pain that is sharp and pleuritic (worsening with inspiration or coughing). Characteristically, the pain is relieved by sitting forward, which reduces the pressure on the inflamed pericardium. A rub can be heard (typically as a scratching sound) and is highly specific; it arises from the fact that the pericardium is a double-walled sac, and inflammation leads to friction of the layers, producing an audible sound. Inflammation may also lead to fluid accumulation and a pericardial effusion, which can be reflected in an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiograph. There is also a risk of tamponade, so patients should be assessed for relevant signs, including pulsus paradoxus, hypotension, tachycardia, and jugular venous distension. If the pericardial effusion is large, a rub may not be audible.

An electrocardiogram can assist in the diagnosis of pericarditis, as diffuse ST-segment elevations are often present — although not always, depending on when the patient presents in the course of the illness.

The most appropriate first-line treatment for acute viral pericarditis is a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID). Treatment duration is typically 1 to 2 weeks or until symptoms resolve. There is no evidence of relative superiority among ibuprofen, aspirin, and indomethacin.

Colchicine is occasionally used to treat acute or recurrent pericarditis and is preferred by some clinicians either alone or in combination with an NSAID.

Key learning point: Appropriate first-line pharmacologic treatment for acute viral pericarditis consists of a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers are contraindicated in myocarditis and pericarditis because they have the potential to interfere with cardiac contractility by altering the calcium gradient in the myocyte.

D) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is used to treat pulmonary embolism (PE), which can cause chest pain and shortness of breath; although the pain associated with PE is sharp, it does not change with bodily position, and a rub is not present. ST-segment changes are not typical for patients with PE, unless there is significant right ventricular strain, and then the changes would not be diffuse (as they are in this patient).

E) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin is used to treat myocardial ischemia, but this diagnosis is unlikely in this patient. Myocardial ischemia is characterized by pain that is usually pressure-like and does not change with bodily position; in addition, there are specific ST-segment changes that involve a certain artery or region with reciprocal changes (rather than the diffuse changes that characterize pericarditis), and a rub is not typically present.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States from Haiti comes to the office because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. For the past few days, he has also had difficulty lying flat due to trouble breathing. Over the past year, he has had intermittent fever, night sweats, and cough but he has not been seen by a physician for evaluation of these symptoms. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). An x-ray of the chest is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Elimination of S2 heart sound splitting with inspiration
Painless erythematous lesions on palms or soles
Prominent "a" wave on jugular venous pressure tracing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is a physiological finding heard during inspiration. It is caused by the early closure of the aortic valve (A2) in relation to the pulmonary valve (P2) when intrathoracic pressure is decreased. In conditions such as aortic stenosis (AS), ventricular septal defect with Eisenmenger syndrome, and left bundle branch block, elimination of S2 splitting can occur because A2 is delayed and superimposed on P2. Although severe, long-standing aortic stenosis can result in fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), chronic AS is not associated with fever or night sweats but with symptoms such as syncope, palpitations, and angina. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications but an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

B) INCORRECT:

Painless erythematous lesions on the palms or soles (Janeway lesions) are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, fever, and night sweats. However, the symptoms of IE have an acute or subacute onset (days to weeks), whereas this patient had fever, night sweats, and a cough for a year before developing dyspnea and fatigue. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, and IE is almost always associated with the development of a new heart murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

On a jugular venous pressure tracing, the “a” wave is caused by atrial contraction in late diastole. A prominent “a” wave is a sign of increased atrial contraction pressure due to restricted filling of the right ventricle (e.g., tricuspid valve stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, cardiac tamponade). In constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular filling is only impaired when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. As a result, all right ventricular filling rapidly occurs in early diastole, producing a prominent and deep x descent and y descent on venous pressure tracing rather than a prominent “a” wave.
Image Description:

A normal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is composed of:
- a wave: atrial contraction
- c wave: tricuspid valve closure
- x descent: atrial relaxation
- v wave: venous refilling of the atria
- y descent: passive filling of right ventricle when the tricuspid valve opens

Common abnormalities of the JVP waveform include:
- Constrictive pericarditis: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure) with a prominent x (exaggerated atrial relaxation) and y (early rapid ventricular filling) descent
- Cardiac tamponade: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure), a prominent x descent (exaggerated atrial relaxation), and a blunt or absent y descent (minimal ventricular filling)
- Tricuspid regurgitation: prominent v wave as the blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium during ventricular systole (atrial diastole), increasing interatrial pressure and volume
- Tricuspid stenosis: giant a wave due to high right atrial systolic pressure
- Atrial septal defect: v wave ≥ a wave due to the left-to-right shunting of blood
- Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block: cannon a waves due to the loss of AV synchronization and contraction of the atria against a closed tricuspid valve
- Atrial fibrillation: absent a waves due to ineffective contraction of the atria

D) CORRECT:

Normally, the decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration expands the compliant right ventricle, resulting in a decrease in jugular venous pressure. In constrictive pericarditis, compliance of the right ventricle is decreased and the right ventricle fails to expand during inspiration. This, alongside a possible increase in baseline jugular venous pressure in constrictive pericarditis due to restricted right ventricular filling during late diastole, leads to an increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration, and therefore, jugular venous distention on inspiration. This phenomenon, which is called Kussmaul sign, can also be seen in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Management options for constrictive pericarditis include NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids, pericardiectomy, and treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., antitubercular or immunomodulatory therapy).

In cardiac tamponade without underlying pericarditis (e.g., traumatic hemopericardium), the jugular venous pressure is increased as a result of impaired right ventricular filling. However, the right ventricle is still compliant and a decrease in intrathoracic pressure can be transmitted to the right ventricle across the fluid-filled pericardial sac. Kussmaul sign would not be expected in traumatic cardiac tamponade.

E) INCORRECT:

A crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped) systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space is a common finding in aortic stenosis (AS). While severe, long-standing AS can result in chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), fever and night sweats are not commonly seen. Finally, symptoms such as syncope, angina, and palpitations are expected in chronic AS, and x-ray would show an enlarged cardiac silhouette rather than the pericardial calcifications seen here.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.
questions.hint: New-onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue alongside pericardial thickening and calcifications on x-ray indicate constrictive pericarditis. In this patient with an immigration history from an endemic region and a prolonged history of night sweats, fever, and cough, the most likely etiology of constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man reports a one-week history of retrosternal chest pain that radiates to his neck and back. The pain developed 3 weeks after an upper respiratory infection resolved and is not accompanied by lightheadedness, dizziness, or diaphoresis. The patient reports that the pain is worse when he is lying down and relieved when he sits upright; it does not change with oral intake. His vital signs are unremarkable. He has normal first and second heart sounds and a systolic rub, best appreciated when he leans forward. His electrocardiogram reveals normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific T-wave changes. Which one of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In an individual with acute viral pericarditis, the addition of moderate-dose colchicine to a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen, results in significantly better rates of remission and recurrence than treatment with an nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug alone. Thus, both drugs are recommended in patients with acute viral pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

C) CORRECT:

In an individual with acute viral pericarditis, the addition of moderate-dose colchicine to a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen, results in significantly better rates of remission and recurrence than treatment with an nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug alone. Thus, both drugs are recommended in patients with acute viral pericarditis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management of acute viral pericarditis involves a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug and colchicine.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

Although most cases of acute pericarditis are attributed to a viral etiology, antiinfluenza therapy, such as oseltamivir, has not been shown to effectively treat acute pericarditis or prevent its recurrence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of dyspnea and intermittent retrosternal chest pain that radiates to her back. She describes the pain as 6 out of 10 in intensity. One week ago, she could not go to work because of fever, runny nose, and a dry cough that lasted 3 days. She has hypertension well-controlled with ramipril. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. Complete blood count and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. Serum troponin T concentration is 0.02 μg/L, and serum creatine kinase concentration is 15 U/L. An ECG shows diffuse concave ST elevation (in I, II, aVF, V3–V6) with reciprocal ST depression in aVR and V1. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Pulmonary artery occlusion on CT angiography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A systolic ejection murmur on auscultation is a typical finding in aortic stenosis, which can manifest with chest pain and dyspnea. A family history of bicuspid aortic valve increases this patient's risk of having bicuspid aortic valve, which is a risk factor for aortic stenosis. However, in patients with aortic stenosis, symptoms typically develop more progressively, usually first manifesting with exertion. Moreover, ECG findings in aortic stenosis include signs of ventricular hypertrophy, not the diffuse ST elevations seen on this patient's ECG.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary artery occlusion on CT angiography confirms pulmonary embolism (PE), which manifests with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea. This patient's smoking history also increases the risk of developing PE. However, she has no signs or symptoms suggestive of deep venous thrombosis, history of prior venous thromboembolism, surgery/immobilization, hemoptysis, or malignancy. Therefore, her Wells score is zero, and a CT angiography is not indicated. Moreover, ECG findings in PE include sinus tachycardia, S1Q3T3 pattern, new right bundle branch block, and right axis deviation, not the diffuse ST elevations seen on this patient's ECG.
Image Description:

12 channel ECG with sinus rhythm, negative T-wave in V1-V5, and S1Q3T3 pattern (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III and negative T-wave in lead III).

Findings of a negative T-wave in the anterior leads and an S1Q3T3 pattern suggest an acute pulmonary embolism.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's acute chest pain and dyspnea in combination with the ECG findings are suggestive of acute pericarditis. This condition is most commonly caused by a viral infection, indicated by the fever, runny nose, and dry cough this patient had 1 week ago. Acute pericarditis typically manifests with acute sharp retrosternal pain that is exacerbated by inspiration and coughing and improves with sitting and leaning forward. However, patients may present with atypical chest pain, as seen in this case. For the diagnosis of acute pericarditis, at least two of the following four criteria must be present: a characteristic chest pain (pleuritic), a pericardial friction rub, typical ECG changes (diffuse, concave-upward ST segment elevations), and new or worsening pericardial effusion on echocardiography. A pericardial high-pitched friction rub on auscultation is present in 85% of patients with acute pericarditis and, in combination with this patient's ECG findings, would confirm the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:
