A valvular vegetation on echocardiography is one of the major Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with chest pain and dyspnea. However, confirming the diagnosis of IE requires the presence of at least one other major criterion (e.g., two positive blood cultures for typical pathogens) or at least three of the minor criteria (underlying heart disease or intravenous drug use, fever, vascular phenomena, immunologic phenomena, positive blood cultures that do not fulfill major criteria), all of which are absent in this patient. Moreover, infective endocarditis would not explain this patient's ECG findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Vessel occlusion on coronary angiography indicates myocardial infarction, which manifests with acute retrosternal chest pain and dyspnea. However, in myocardial infarction, the chest pain is usually persistent rather than intermittent; the pain is commonly described as a dull, squeezing pressure or tightness. Additionally, ECG findings include ST elevation in anatomically contiguous leads that correspond to the infarcted area, not the diffuse ST elevations seen here. Moreover, troponin T would be increased in patients with myocardial infarction.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ∼ 83/min
- Normal cardiac axis: R > S in leads I and aVF
- Normal QRS complex
- ST elevation in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF; blue overlay) with reciprocal ST depression in aVL (red overlay) and pathological Q waves in III (example indicated by green circle overlay)
questions.hint: The 12-lead ECG shows diffuse, concave, upward-sloping ST segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V3–V6, with reciprocal ST depression in aVR and V1.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain for 3 days. The pain is retrosternal, 8 out of 10 in intensity, increases with respiration, and decreases while sitting upright and leaning forward. He has nausea and myalgia. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched grating sound between S1 and S2. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dl


Glucose
93 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


Troponin I
0.23 ng/mL


An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations in all leads. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of acute myocardial infarction (MI) that leads to mitral regurgitation with subsequent hypotension and pulmonary edema. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with ST elevations in anatomically contiguous leads on ECG.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary infarction is most commonly caused by pulmonary embolism (PE), which can also present with chest pain and nonspecific ST elevation. However, other common features of PE would be expected, including dyspnea, tachypnea, cough, hypotension, or signs of right ventricular pressure overload on ECG (e.g., right axis deviation). The absence of these symptoms in this case, as well as the presence of a friction rub on auscultation, make pulmonary embolism and therefore pulmonary infarction unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Mediastinitis may occur as a result of esophageal disorders (e.g., Boerhaave syndrome). Patients with Boerhaave syndrome often present with a history of explosive vomiting and symptoms such as retrosternal pain and mediastinal emphysema (Mackler triad). The retrosternal pain seen in this patient makes Boerhaave syndrome an important differential diagnosis. However, in this case, the patient's history, auscultatory and ECG findings are suggestive of a different disease.

D) CORRECT:

Pericarditis is a common cause of cardiac tamponade; it may occur in cases in which the pericardium becomes scarred and less elastic, while increased amounts of inflammatory fluids are secreted into the pericardial space. Cardiac tamponade can lead to hemodynamic compromise; therefore, treatment with pericardiocentesis is indicated.

Another complication of acute pericarditis is chronic, constrictive pericarditis, which may develop after several years.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventricular aneurysm is a late (> 3 weeks) complication of myocardial infarction (MI) that presents with persistent ST elevations and T wave inversions on ECG and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and thromboembolisms. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with more specific findings on ECG. Considering the timing and that MI is unlikely, ventricular aneurysm can be ruled out.
questions.hint: The patient's 3-day history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up, in conjunction with a friction rub on cardiac auscultation, nausea, and myalgia, is suggestive of acute pericarditis. The ECG finding of ST elevations in all leads with a mild increase in troponin I further support the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of sharp, substernal chest pain that is worse with inspiration and relieved with leaning forward. He has also had nausea and myalgias. His father has coronary artery disease. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched rubbing sound between S1 and S2 that is best heard at the left sternal border. ECG shows depressed PR interval and diffuse ST elevations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dressler syndrome is an autoimmune complication that manifests as pericarditis weeks after myocardial infarction. This patient without coronary artery disease or past myocardial infarction is unlikely to develop this type of pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although substernal chest pain should raise concern for acute myocardial infarction (MI), this patient does not have risk factors for coronary artery disease (e.g., diabetes mellitus, tobacco use) aside from family history. Furthermore, acute MI does not manifest with positional chest pain, friction rub, or noncontiguous ST elevations. MI may cause pericarditis within 1–3 days (i.e., postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis), but this patient has no history of recent MI.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis is the most common cause of pericarditis in endemic countries. However, tuberculosis pericarditis is unlikely in a patient who has no characteristic symptoms (cough, weight loss, night sweats). Furthermore, he has no demographic risk factors (travel to endemic countries, work in hospitals/nursing homes, incarceration) nor medical risk factors (congenital or acquired immunodeficiency) of tuberculosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiovascular involvement is common in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), including pericarditis and endocarditis (Libman-Sacks). Pericarditis in patients with SLE is most commonly subclinical, noted only on echocardiogram. This patient presents with symptomatic pericarditis, has no signs of SLE, and has no family history of autoimmune disease.

E) CORRECT:

The most common causes of acute pericarditis are 1.) idiopathic (assumed viral etiology), followed by 2.) cases of confirmed viral etiology. The most common causes of viral pericarditis are coxsackievirus B and echovirus; other pathogens include hepatitis viruses, influenza virus, measles virus, mumps virus, varicella virus, and HIV.

Idiopathic cases are presumed to be viral because efforts to confirm etiology are not routinely pursued due to the expenses involved, the inaccessibility of pericardial tissue/fluid, and the time delay and inaccuracy of viral studies (e.g., culture, PCR, viral serology). In most cases, clinical management is not changed by these results.
questions.hint: Sharp, pleuritic, and positional chest pain and a pericardial friction rub in combination with an ECG showing diffuse ST elevations indicate acute pericarditis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a dry cough and severe chest pain beginning that morning. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with inferior wall myocardial infarction. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography shows diffuse ST elevations. Serum studies show a troponin I of 0.2 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade can result from cardiac wall rupture, a complication of myocardial infarction. Cardiac tamponade would result in acute-onset chest pain and tachypnea, as in this patient, and ventricular free wall rupture can also result in increased troponin levels. However, patients with cardiac tamponade would also have features such as dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, and increased jugular venous pressure. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds rather than a pericardial rub would be heard. An ECG would show low voltage complexes, electrical alternans, and, possibly, tall precordial T waves. Moreover, rupture of the cardiac wall typically occurs within 2 weeks after an MI and is more commonly seen in anterior and/or lateral wall infarcts than with inferior wall infarcts.

B) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis has, on rare occasions, been reported after MI. However, it is a late complication that develops months to years after MI. Moreover, it would manifest with edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, hypotension, increased jugular venous pressure, a pericardial knock, the Kussmaul sign, and pulsus paradoxus, none of which are seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Reinfarction, which is an important consideration in any patient with a recent MI, can manifest with acute-onset chest pain, tachypnea, increased troponin levels, and ST elevations. A dry cough (cardiac asthma) may also be present in some patients with MI. However, a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration would not be expected in reinfarction. Moreover, the ST elevations would be localized to certain leads, in contrast to the diffuse ST elevations in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Early infarct-associated pericarditis can manifest with fever, tachypnea, chest pain, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST-elevation on ECG. However, early infarct-associated pericarditis typically occurs within a few days after MI, whereas this patient's MI occurred 2 months ago.

E) CORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome), a type of postcardiac injury syndrome, usually occurs 2–10 weeks after MI due to immune-complex mediated damage (type III hypersensitivity reaction) in the pericardium. The exact mechanism of immune-complex formation in Dressler syndrome is not completely understood, but the release of neo-antigens from the infarcted myocardium is suspected to play a role. Patients typically present with features of acute pericarditis such as fever, tachypnea, chest pain that is worse during inspiration and relieved by leaning forward, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), a pericardial rub, increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG. Dressler syndrome may also cause pericardial effusion.

Dressler syndrome is treated with NSAIDs, preferably high-dose aspirin.
questions.hint: The timing of this patient's symptoms in relation to his recent myocardial infarction (MI), the high-pitched scratching sound heard on auscultation, and the presence of diffuse ST elevations suggest a particular diagnosis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of sharp chest pain that worsens with inspiration and improves when leaning forward. He denies recent trauma or illicit drug use. A friction rub is heard over the precordium (see reports).

Temperature
38°C


ECG: Diffuse ST-segment elevations in multiple leads with PR-segment depressions
Chest X-ray: Normal

Which of the following interventions is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are reserved for pericarditis cases unresponsive to first-line therapies, or when an autoimmune etiology is identified. In this young patient with likely viral or idiopathic pericarditis, corticosteroids are not indicated due to the risk of recurrence and are more aggressive than necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for hemodynamic compromise, such as cardiac tamponade. This patient shows no signs of tamponade, such as hypotension or pulsus paradoxus, and the chest x-ray is normal, indicating no significant effusion. The management of acute pericarditis is primarily anti-inflammatory.

C) CORRECT:

Acute pericarditis manifests with pleuritic chest pain relieved by leaning forward, a pericardial friction rub, and ECG findings of diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression. High-dose nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen are the first-line treatment, as they reduce inflammation by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes and decreasing prostaglandin synthesis. This approach addresses both the pain and the underlying inflammation. Colchicine may be added to reduce recurrence rates, emphasizing the importance of targeted anti-inflammatory therapy in managing acute pericarditis.

Key learning point: Acute pericarditis is characterized by chest pain, pericardial friction rub, and ECG changes such as diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression; NSAIDs like ibuprofen are the first-line treatment to reduce inflammation and relieve pain.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient's presentation suggests viral or idiopathic pericarditis, not bacterial. Bacterial pericarditis typically presents with high fevers and hemodynamic instability, often with predisposing conditions. The normal chest x-ray and lack of severe systemic signs do not support bacterial infection.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents with two days of sharp, pleuritic chest pain that improves when he leans forward. He denies recent infections or trauma. He has no jugular venous distension. On examination, a scratchy sound is heard along the left sternal border (see report).


Heart rate
86/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
14/min


Temperature
37.5 °C


ECG: Diffuse ST-segment elevations without reciprocal changes
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including sharp, pleuritic chest pain that improves when leaning forward, a pericardial friction rub, and diffuse ST-segment elevations on ECG, are indicative of acute pericarditis. High-dose nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the first-line treatment due to their ability to reduce pericardial inflammation and alleviate pain. NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase enzymes, decreasing prostaglandin synthesis and the inflammatory response. Clinical guidelines recommend NSAIDs, often combined with colchicine, to decrease the risk of recurrence. In the absence of complications like cardiac tamponade, NSAIDs are the most appropriate initial management for acute pericarditis.

Key learning point: Acute pericarditis is characterized by chest pain relieved by sitting forward, a pericardial friction rub, and diffuse ST elevation on ECG, and is typically treated with NSAIDs as first-line therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Emergent coronary angiography is used for ST-elevation myocardial infarction. The patient's diffuse ST-segment elevations, pleuritic chest pain, and pericardial friction rub suggest pericarditis, not an occlusive coronary event. The clinical context does not support coronary angiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for cardiac tamponade, characterized by hemodynamic instability and signs like jugular venous distension. This patient is hemodynamically stable, with no evidence of tamponade physiology. The absence of these critical features makes urgent pericardiocentesis inappropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are used for bacterial infections. The patient's presentation, including low-grade fever and pericardial friction rub, suggests viral or idiopathic pericarditis, not bacterial. There are no signs of severe systemic infection to warrant antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with a two-day history of sharp, pleuritic chest pain relieved by leaning forward. He had a mild upper respiratory tract infection last week. Auscultation reveals a high-pitched, scratching sound along the left sternal border throughout the cardiac cycle (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
98/min


Blood pressure
120/76 mmHg


Temperature
38.1°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Troponin T
0.05 mg/L
0 - 0.1 mg/L


Troponin I
0.2 mg/L
0 - 0.4 mg/L


WBC
11.2 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L



Electrocardiogram: Diffuse ST-segment elevations with no reciprocal changes
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous corticosteroids are reserved for pericarditis cases with contraindications to NSAIDs, non-response to first-line agents, or autoimmune or uremic etiologies. In viral pericarditis, corticosteroids are associated with higher recurrence rates and are not recommended as initial treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated for bacterial infections. The patient's presentation, including pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub, and diffuse ST-segment elevations, is consistent with viral pericarditis, not bacterial pericarditis, which would present with more severe systemic symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for cardiac tamponade or large effusions causing hemodynamic compromise. This patient shows no signs of hemodynamic instability or significant effusion, as evidenced by stable vital signs and the absence of echocardiographic findings.

D) CORRECT:

Acute pericarditis manifests with sharp, pleuritic chest pain that improves when leaning forward, a pericardial friction rub, and diffuse ST-segment elevations on electrocardiogram. These findings, along with a history of a recent upper respiratory tract infection, suggest a viral etiology. Oral ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is the first-line treatment for acute pericarditis. It reduces inflammation and alleviates pain, addressing the underlying inflammatory process.

Key learning point: A pericardial friction rub is a classic auscultatory finding in pericarditis, often following a viral infection.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of sharp, central chest pain for two days. The pain worsens when lying flat and improves when leaning forward. He is previously healthy. Auscultation reveals a scratching sound at the left sternal border during both systole and diastole (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
92/min


Blood pressure
120/76 mmHg


Temperature
38°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



C-reactive peptide
10 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L


Troponin I
0.2 mg/L
0 - 0.4 mg/L



ECG: Diffuse ST-segment elevations in multiple leads with PR segment depression
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous corticosteroids are not first-line treatment for idiopathic or viral pericarditis due to the risk of recurrence and adverse effects. NSAIDs are preferred for their efficacy and safety profile. Corticosteroids are reserved for cases refractory to NSAIDs or associated with systemic autoimmune disorders.

B) CORRECT:

Acute pericarditis manifests with sharp, pleuritic chest pain that worsens when lying flat and improves when leaning forward. The presence of a pericardial friction rub and ECG findings of diffuse ST-segment elevations with PR segment depression indicate an inflammatory process. High-dose nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, are the first-line treatment due to their anti-inflammatory properties, which help reduce pericardial inflammation and alleviate pain. This approach minimizes the risk of complications like pericardial effusion or chronic constrictive pericarditis. Colchicine may be added to reduce recurrence risk.

Key learning point: The best initial treatment for acute pericarditis is NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen, which help reduce inflammation and alleviate pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Urgent pericardiocentesis is indicated for cardiac tamponade, characterized by hemodynamic compromise. This patient has stable vital signs and no evidence of tamponade physiology, such as hypotension or pulsus paradoxus, making pericardiocentesis unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated for bacterial pericarditis, which typically presents with high-grade fever and systemic illness. This patient’s presentation, including sharp, positional chest pain, a pericardial friction rub, and ECG changes, suggests viral or idiopathic pericarditis, not a bacterial infection.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of progressive fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and ankle swelling. She has a 10-year history of systemic lupus erythematosus and has not had any recent flares, but reports mild chest discomfort. Examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure with a prominent x and y descent, muffled heart sounds, and an early diastolic sound distinct from an S3. There is no pulsus paradoxus. Laboratory tests, including inflammatory markers, are within normal limits (see report).
Echocardiogram: Thickened pericardial layers with normal left ventricular systolic function
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy involves impaired ventricular filling due to myocardial stiffness, often with biatrial enlargement and normal pericardial thickness. The echocardiogram shows thickened pericardial layers, not typical of restrictive cardiomyopathy. The early diastolic sound and jugular venous pulse findings are more indicative of a pericardial process.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, leading to impaired cardiac filling. It typically presents with pulsus paradoxus, which is absent here. Echocardiography shows thickened pericardial layers rather than a large effusion, and the presence of a pericardial knock and prominent x and y descents in jugular venous pressure suggest constrictive pericarditis instead.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic mitral stenosis presents with a diastolic rumbling murmur and an opening snap, due to valvular changes. The echocardiogram shows thickened pericardial layers and preserved left ventricular function, not consistent with mitral stenosis. The jugular venous pulse findings suggest a pericardial rather than valvular issue.

D) CORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis manifests with impaired diastolic filling due to fibrosis and thickening of the pericardial layers, often secondary to chronic inflammation, such as in systemic lupus erythematosus. This condition results in elevated jugular venous pressure with a prominent x and y descent and an early diastolic sound known as a pericardial knock, distinct from an S3. Echocardiography shows thickened pericardium and preserved left ventricular systolic function, consistent with constrictive pericarditis.

Key learning point: Constrictive pericarditis in SLE can present with jugular venous distention, distant heart sounds, and a pericardial knock, and should be considered when these signs are present.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man who recently immigrated from Indonesia comes to your clinic with worsening shortness of breath and swollen extremities for the past 3 months. He reports a 4-kg weight loss and intermittent fevers over the last 6 months. On examination, he has pitting pedal edema and abdominal distension. Applying pressure over the right upper quadrant of the abdomen results in persistent distention of the jugular veins. A chest x-ray shows cavernous infiltrates in the left and right upper lobes and a calcified cardiac silhouette. Which one of the following is most likely to be found on cardiovascular examination?

choices.text: Absent jugular venous pulse y descent.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In acute pericarditis, inflammation of the pericardial layers can cause friction as they move during the cardiac cycle, creating an audible friction rub on cardiac auscultation. While a friction rub is characteristic of the acute phase of pericarditis, a different heart sound is pathognomonic for chronic constrictive pericarditis, in which the ventricles are working against a calcified and thickened pericardium.

B) INCORRECT:

A fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by a late diastolic contraction of the atria and is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, and ischemic heart disease. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is an important differential diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis because it can manifest similarly. However, it does not cause calcification of the cardiac silhouette. An S4 is not a physical exam finding of constrictive pericarditis, most likely because the rigid pericardial sac impairs atrial contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

The y descent of the jugular venous pulse waveform corresponds to the emptying of the right atrium following the opening of the tricuspid valve. Absent y descent would indicate resistance to all phases of diastolic filling, which is seen in cardiac tamponade. In constrictive pericarditis, the early phase of diastolic filling is unchanged, but the mid-late phase is met with resistance. This, coupled with the high jugular venous distention of chronic venous congestion, produces a prominent y descent that is accentuated in the early phase as filling drops rapidly from a higher peak pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is characteristic of the prolonged left ventricular total ejection time seen in aortic stenosis (AS). AS would cause signs and symptoms of left heart failure, but not the symptoms of right heart failure seen in this patient. Furthermore, calcification in AS is limited to the aortic valve and does not involve the entire cardiac silhouette, as seen here.

E) CORRECT:

A pericardial knock is a high-pitched, early-diastolic sound that sounds like a premature S3. A pericardial knock is often heard on auscultation in constrictive pericarditis due to the abrupt halting of diastolic ventricular relaxation and filling by the rigid pericardial sac. In constrictive pericarditis, reduced ventricular filling leads to manifestations of reduced cardiac output (forward failure), such as fatigue and/or dyspnea, as well as those of fluid overload (backward failure), such as jugular venous distention, positive Kussmaul sign, hepatomegaly, and the clinical features seen in this patient.

While tuberculosis is the most likely underlying cause of constrictive pericarditis in this patient, other etiologies include prior cardiac surgery, radiation therapy to the chest, viral infection, and connective tissue diseases.

Key learning point: A high-pitched early diastolic pericardial knock is a classic auscultatory finding in constrictive pericarditis due to abrupt cessation of ventricular filling by a rigid pericardium.
questions.hint: This patient's history of immigration from an endemic region, his clinical presentation of fever and weight loss, as well as the cavernous lesions seen on x-ray indicate tuberculosis. His dyspnea, pitting edema, abdominal distention, and positive hepatojugular reflux in the context of a calcified cardiac silhouette suggest constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 64-year-old man who recently immigrated from Haiti. He presents with a 3-week history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. In the past few days, he has developed orthopnea. Over the past year, he has experienced intermittent fever, night sweats, and cough, but has not previously sought medical evaluation. His temperature is 37.8°C. A chest x-ray is provided. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Elimination of S2 heart sound splitting with inspiration.
Painless erythematous lesions on palms or soles.
Prominent "a" wave on jugular venous pressure tracing.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is a physiological finding heard during inspiration. It is caused by the early closure of the aortic valve (A2) in relation to the pulmonary valve (P2) when intrathoracic pressure is decreased. In conditions such as aortic stenosis (AS), ventricular septal defect with Eisenmenger syndrome, and left bundle branch block, elimination of S2 splitting can occur because A2 is delayed and superimposed on P2. Although severe, long-standing aortic stenosis can result in fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), chronic AS is not associated with fever or night sweats but with symptoms such as syncope, palpitations, and angina. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications but an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

B) INCORRECT:

Painless erythematous lesions on the palms or soles (Janeway lesions) are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, fever, and night sweats. However, the symptoms of IE have an acute or subacute onset (days to weeks), whereas this patient had fever, night sweats, and a cough for a year before developing dyspnea and fatigue. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, and IE is almost always associated with the development of a new heart murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

A crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped) systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space is a common finding in aortic stenosis (AS). While severe, long-standing AS can result in chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), fever and night sweats are not commonly seen. Finally, symptoms such as syncope, angina, and palpitations are expected in chronic AS, and x-ray would show an enlarged cardiac silhouette rather than the pericardial calcifications seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Normally, the decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration expands the compliant right ventricle, resulting in a decrease in jugular venous pressure. In constrictive pericarditis, compliance of the right ventricle is decreased and the right ventricle fails to expand during inspiration. This, alongside a possible increase in baseline jugular venous pressure in constrictive pericarditis due to restricted right ventricular filling during late diastole, leads to an increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration, and therefore, jugular venous distention on inspiration. This phenomenon, which is called Kussmaul sign, can also be seen in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Management options for constrictive pericarditis include NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids, pericardiectomy, and treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., antitubercular or immunomodulatory therapy).

In cardiac tamponade without underlying pericarditis (e.g., traumatic hemopericardium), the jugular venous pressure is increased as a result of impaired right ventricular filling. However, the right ventricle is still compliant and a decrease in intrathoracic pressure can be transmitted to the right ventricle across the fluid-filled pericardial sac. Kussmaul sign would not be expected in traumatic cardiac tamponade.

Key learning point: Kussmaul sign—jugular venous distention that worsens with inspiration—is a classic physical finding in constrictive pericarditis due to impaired right ventricular filling.

E) INCORRECT:

On a jugular venous pressure tracing, the “a” wave is caused by atrial contraction in late diastole. A prominent “a” wave is a sign of increased atrial contraction pressure due to restricted filling of the right ventricle (e.g., tricuspid valve stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, cardiac tamponade). In constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular filling is only impaired when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. As a result, all right ventricular filling rapidly occurs in early diastole, producing a prominent and deep x descent and y descent on venous pressure tracing rather than a prominent “a” wave.
questions.hint: New-onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue alongside pericardial thickening and calcifications on x-ray indicate constrictive pericarditis. In this patient with an immigration history from an endemic region and a prolonged history of night sweats, fever, and cough, the most likely etiology of constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to your clinic with a one-week history of retrosternal chest pain radiating to his neck and back. The pain began 3 weeks after he recovered from an upper respiratory infection. He does not have lightheadedness, dizziness, or diaphoresis. He reports that the pain worsens when lying down and improves when sitting upright; it is not affected by oral intake. Vital signs are normal. Cardiac examination reveals normal first and second heart sounds and a systolic rub, best heard when he leans forward. His electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific T-wave changes. Which one of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In an individual with acute viral pericarditis, the addition of moderate-dose colchicine to a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen, results in significantly better rates of remission and recurrence than treatment with an nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug alone. Thus, both drugs are recommended in patients with acute viral pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

C) CORRECT:

In an individual with acute viral pericarditis, the addition of moderate-dose colchicine to a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen, results in significantly better rates of remission and recurrence than treatment with an nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug alone. Thus, both drugs are recommended in patients with acute viral pericarditis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management of acute viral pericarditis involves a high-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug and colchicine.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, appear to be associated with an increased risk for recurrent pericarditis and are not routinely recommended.

Although most cases of acute pericarditis are attributed to a viral etiology, antiinfluenza therapy, such as oseltamivir, has not been shown to effectively treat acute pericarditis or prevent its recurrence.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of sharp, retrosternal chest pain. The pain is rated 8 out of 10 in intensity, worsens with respiration, and improves when he sits upright and leans forward. He also reports nausea and myalgia. His temperature is 37.3°C, pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, you hear a high-pitched grating sound between S1 and S2. The remainder of the examination is normal. Serum studies show:


Urea, blood
5.7 mmol/L (2.1–8.0)


Glucose, fasting, blood
5.2 mmol/L (4.0–6.0)


Creatinine, blood
62 μmol/L (49–93)


Troponin I, blood
230 ng/L (≤ 45)


An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations in all leads. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary infarction is most commonly caused by pulmonary embolism (PE), which can also present with chest pain and nonspecific ST elevation. However, other common features of PE would be expected, including dyspnea, tachypnea, cough, hypotension, or signs of right ventricular pressure overload on ECG (e.g., right axis deviation). The absence of these symptoms in this case, as well as the presence of a friction rub on auscultation, make pulmonary embolism and therefore pulmonary infarction unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Pericarditis is a common cause of cardiac tamponade; it may occur in cases in which the pericardium becomes scarred and less elastic, while increased amounts of inflammatory fluids are secreted into the pericardial space. Cardiac tamponade can lead to hemodynamic compromise; therefore, treatment with pericardiocentesis is indicated.

Another complication of acute pericarditis is chronic, constrictive pericarditis, which may develop after several years.

Key learning point: Acute pericarditis can lead to cardiac tamponade due to accumulation of inflammatory fluid in the pericardial space, causing hemodynamic compromise.

C) INCORRECT:

Mediastinitis may occur as a result of esophageal disorders (e.g., Boerhaave syndrome). Patients with Boerhaave syndrome often present with a history of explosive vomiting and symptoms such as retrosternal pain and mediastinal emphysema (Mackler triad). The retrosternal pain seen in this patient makes Boerhaave syndrome an important differential diagnosis. However, in this case, the patient's history, auscultatory and ECG findings are suggestive of a different disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of acute myocardial infarction (MI) that leads to mitral regurgitation with subsequent hypotension and pulmonary edema. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with ST elevations in anatomically contiguous leads on ECG.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventricular aneurysm is a late (> 3 weeks) complication of myocardial infarction (MI) that presents with persistent ST elevations and T wave inversions on ECG and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and thromboembolisms. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with more specific findings on ECG. Considering the timing and that MI is unlikely, ventricular aneurysm can be ruled out.
questions.hint: The patient's 3-day history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up, in conjunction with a friction rub on cardiac auscultation, nausea, and myalgia, is suggestive of acute pericarditis. The ECG finding of ST elevations in all leads with a mild increase in troponin I further support the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-week history of sharp, substernal chest pain that worsens with inspiration and is relieved by leaning forward. He also reports nausea and myalgias. His father has coronary artery disease. His temperature is 37.3°C, pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, you hear a high-pitched rubbing sound between S1 and S2, best heard at the left sternal border. ECG shows a depressed PR interval and diffuse ST elevations. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although substernal chest pain should raise concern for acute myocardial infarction (MI), this patient does not have risk factors for coronary artery disease (e.g., diabetes mellitus, tobacco use) aside from family history. Furthermore, acute MI does not manifest with positional chest pain, friction rub, or noncontiguous ST elevations. MI may cause pericarditis within 1–3 days (i.e., postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis), but this patient has no history of recent MI.

B) CORRECT:

The most common causes of acute pericarditis are 1.) idiopathic (assumed viral etiology), followed by 2.) cases of confirmed viral etiology. The most common causes of viral pericarditis are coxsackievirus B and echovirus; other pathogens include hepatitis viruses, influenza virus, measles virus, mumps virus, varicella virus, and HIV.

Idiopathic cases are presumed to be viral because efforts to confirm etiology are not routinely pursued due to the expenses involved, the inaccessibility of pericardial tissue/fluid, and the time delay and inaccuracy of viral studies (e.g., culture, PCR, viral serology). In most cases, clinical management is not changed by these results.

Key learning point: Acute pericarditis in young, otherwise healthy adults is most commonly caused by a viral infection, particularly coxsackievirus B and echovirus.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis is the most common cause of pericarditis in endemic countries. However, tuberculosis pericarditis is unlikely in a patient who has no characteristic symptoms (cough, weight loss, night sweats). Furthermore, he has no demographic risk factors (travel to endemic countries, work in hospitals/nursing homes, incarceration) nor medical risk factors (congenital or acquired immunodeficiency) of tuberculosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Dressler syndrome is an autoimmune complication that manifests as pericarditis weeks after myocardial infarction. This patient without coronary artery disease or past myocardial infarction is unlikely to develop this type of pericarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiovascular involvement is common in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), including pericarditis and endocarditis (Libman-Sacks). Pericarditis in patients with SLE is most commonly subclinical, noted only on echocardiogram. This patient presents with symptomatic pericarditis, has no signs of SLE, and has no family history of autoimmune disease.
questions.hint: Sharp, pleuritic, and positional chest pain and a pericardial friction rub in combination with an ECG showing diffuse ST elevations indicate acute pericarditis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 55-year-old man in the emergency department with a dry cough and severe chest pain that began this morning. He was diagnosed with an inferior wall myocardial infarction two months ago. His temperature is 38.5°C, pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, there is a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while he is sitting upright and during expiration. The remainder of the examination is normal. Electrocardiography shows diffuse ST elevations. Serum troponin I is 200 ng/L (≤ 45). Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis has, on rare occasions, been reported after MI. However, it is a late complication that develops months to years after MI. Moreover, it would manifest with edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, hypotension, increased jugular venous pressure, a pericardial knock, the Kussmaul sign, and pulsus paradoxus, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome), a type of postcardiac injury syndrome, usually occurs 2–10 weeks after MI due to immune-complex mediated damage (type III hypersensitivity reaction) in the pericardium. The exact mechanism of immune-complex formation in Dressler syndrome is not completely understood, but the release of neo-antigens from the infarcted myocardium is suspected to play a role. Patients typically present with features of acute pericarditis such as fever, tachypnea, chest pain that is worse during inspiration and relieved by leaning forward, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), a pericardial rub, increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG. Dressler syndrome may also cause pericardial effusion.

Dressler syndrome is treated with NSAIDs, preferably high-dose aspirin.

Key learning point: Dressler syndrome is an immune-mediated pericarditis occurring 2–10 weeks after myocardial infarction, presenting with chest pain, fever, pericardial rub, and diffuse ST elevations on ECG.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade can result from cardiac wall rupture, a complication of myocardial infarction. Cardiac tamponade would result in acute-onset chest pain and tachypnea, as in this patient, and ventricular free wall rupture can also result in increased troponin levels. However, patients with cardiac tamponade would also have features such as dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, and increased jugular venous pressure. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds rather than a pericardial rub would be heard. An ECG would show low voltage complexes, electrical alternans, and, possibly, tall precordial T waves. Moreover, rupture of the cardiac wall typically occurs within 2 weeks after an MI and is more commonly seen in anterior and/or lateral wall infarcts than with inferior wall infarcts.

D) INCORRECT:

Early infarct-associated pericarditis can manifest with fever, tachypnea, chest pain, a dry cough (due to inflammation of the mediastinal pleura adjoining the pericardium), increased troponin levels, and diffuse ST-elevation on ECG. However, early infarct-associated pericarditis typically occurs within a few days after MI, whereas this patient's MI occurred 2 months ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Reinfarction, which is an important consideration in any patient with a recent MI, can manifest with acute-onset chest pain, tachypnea, increased troponin levels, and ST elevations. A dry cough (cardiac asthma) may also be present in some patients with MI. However, a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration would not be expected in reinfarction. Moreover, the ST elevations would be localized to certain leads, in contrast to the diffuse ST elevations in this patient.
questions.hint: The timing of this patient's symptoms in relation to his recent myocardial infarction (MI), the high-pitched scratching sound heard on auscultation, and the presence of diffuse ST elevations suggest a particular diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with 3 days of sharp retrosternal chest pain that worsens with inspiration and improves when sitting forward. He has a fever, and a friction rub is audible on auscultation. ECG shows diffuse ST elevations with PR depression in multiple leads. Troponin I is mildly elevated at 0.8 ng/mL (normal < 0.04). What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chest CT with contrast can evaluate pericardial thickness and effusion but is not first-line imaging for this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is indicated for acute coronary syndrome with significant troponin elevation and localized ECG changes but is not appropriate for initial evaluation of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

While anti-inflammatory therapy is appropriate treatment for this patient's condition, the diagnostic workup should be completed first.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Echocardiography is the appropriate next step to complete the diagnostic workup for pericarditis. Echocardiography can evaluate for pericardial effusion and rule out complications such as tamponade.

E) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is indicated for large effusions, tamponade, and management of effusive-constrictive pericarditis. This patient has no signs of hemodynamic compromise, and the presence of effusion has not yet been determined. Diagnostic echocardiography should be performed first.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with chest pain that started 8 hours ago after a recent upper respiratory infection. The pain is sharp and intermittent, rated 7/10, and worsens when lying down. Vital signs are BP, 135/80; P, 88; R, 18; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F). On examination, heart sounds are normal and no murmurs are heard. Initial ECG is shown. Troponin I is mildly elevated at 0.8 ng/mL (normal < 0.04). Bedside echocardiogram is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombolytic therapy is not appropriate in this patient. The ECG findings show diffuse ST elevations and PR depressions characteristic of pericarditis, not the regional ST elevations seen in STEMI.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids such as prednisone are not first-line therapy for this patient's condition and are usually considered in severe disease or in disease caused by uremia, connective tissue disease, or autoreactivity.

C) INCORRECT:

Dual antiplatelet therapy is appropriate for acute coronary syndrome. However, diffuse ST elevations with PR depressions and mild troponin elevation in this clinical context suggest pericarditis rather than myocardial infarction.

D) INCORRECT:

A diffuse ST elevation pattern with PR depression is characteristic of pericarditis, not acute coronary syndrome. Cardiac catheterization is not indicated for pericarditis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- although acute pericarditis is often self-limited, NSAIDs and colchicine can alleviate symptoms and reduce recurrence.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with worsening dyspnea and fatigue. He states that three days ago he was seen at a different hospital for sharp, pleuritic retrosternal pain and diagnosed with “some -itis related to my heart,” and discharged with medication. Vital signs are BP, 85/60; P, 120. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention and distant heart sounds with clear lung sounds bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic condition that develops over months to years, not acutely over several days. While it can cause jugular venous distention, it typically presents with a pericardial knock rather than distant heart sounds.

B) INCORRECT:

Myocardial infarction is generally not associated with Beck triad; an alternative diagnosis is more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax causes hypotension and jugular venous distention but is associated with decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on the affected side. The heart sounds would not be characteristically distant, and the initial chest pain episode suggests a different underlying process.

D) INCORRECT:

Massive pulmonary embolism can cause hypotension and jugular venous distention, but distant heart sounds and evolution of symptoms from the initial chest pain are not characteristic features of pulmonary embolism. Another diagnosis is more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The patient's initial presentation is consistent with acute pericarditis. The subsequent development of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distention represents Beck triad, which is classic for cardiac tamponade as a complication of pericarditis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with chest pain that began yesterday evening. The pain is sharp and worsens with inspiration. He denies trauma, recent travel, or cardiac risk factors. Vital signs are normal. Physical exam reveals a scratching sound at the left sternal border during expiration while leaning forward. ECG shows diffuse ST elevations. What is the most appropriate initial therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prednisone should only be considered in severe cases or in pericarditis caused by uremia, connective tissue disease, or autoreactivity. It is not indicated as first-line therapy for uncomplicated acute pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is used for treatment of heart failure if present in pericarditis patients, but is not appropriate in this patient with uncomplicated pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Digoxin is used for treatment of concurrent atrial fibrillation in heart failure patients with pericarditis, but is not appropriate in this patient with uncomplicated pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Opioid analgesics do not address the underlying inflammatory process in pericarditis and are not appropriate first-line treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – NSAIDs are the mainstays of therapy for acute pericarditis and can alleviate symptoms and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with 4 days of progressive chest pain and dyspnea. She has a 2-year history of metastatic breast cancer and is currently receiving chemotherapy. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 108; T, 38.8°C (101.8°F); oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, distant heart sounds, and a pericardial friction rub. ECG shows diffuse ST elevations with PR depression. Bedside echocardiography shows a large pericardial effusion with early diastolic collapse of the right ventricle. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics and reassessment in 12 hours
Hospital admission for observation and serial echocardiograms
Indomethacin and colchicine with outpatient follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While bacterial pericarditis is possible, the patient's cancer history and clinical presentation, including signs of early tamponade, are more consistent with malignant pericarditis. Delaying definitive treatment for empiric antibiotics is inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

While hospital admission is appropriate, this patient has suspected malignant pericarditis with a large effusion and early signs of cardiac tamponade. Observation alone is inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient's presentation is consistent with pericarditis and early cardiac tamponade, not pulmonary embolism. Further imaging would delay necessary urgent intervention for the suspected malignant pericardial effusion.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has multiple indicators of poor prognosis, including fever > 38°C, large pericardial effusion, and suspected malignant pericarditis. These findings should prompt hospital admission rather than outpatient anti-inflammatory therapy.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's cancer history, fever > 38°C, and large pericardial effusion with early tamponade physiology suggest malignant pericarditis. These findings indicate urgent cardiology consultation for pericardiocentesis, as malignant effusions commonly require surgical drainage.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of sharp, retrosternal chest pain. The pain worsens with deep inspiration and when he lies down but improves when he sits up and leans forward. He reports a recent upper respiratory infection that resolved last week. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation is unremarkable. An ECG shows widespread concave ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) presents with chest pain and ST elevation, the pain is typically described as crushing pressure, not sharp or pleuritic. The pain of a STEMI is not usually positional. Furthermore, the ST elevation in STEMI is typically convex (tombstone-shaped) and localized to a specific coronary artery territory, often with reciprocal ST depression in other leads, which is different from the diffuse concave elevation seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Prinzmetal angina, or vasospastic angina, can cause ST-segment elevation due to transient coronary artery spasm. However, the associated chest pain is typically anginal in quality (pressure-like) rather than pleuritic and positional. This condition is not associated with fever or a preceding viral illness, and the ECG changes are transient, resolving when the vasospasm and symptoms subside.

C) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary embolism (PE) can cause sharp, pleuritic chest pain and tachycardia. However, the pain is not characteristically relieved by leaning forward. While PE can cause a variety of ECG changes, the most common finding is sinus tachycardia. The classic S1Q3T3 pattern is infrequent, and diffuse concave ST elevation with PR depression is not a typical feature of PE.

D) CORRECT:

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardial sac, most commonly caused by a viral infection, which is consistent with this patient's recent upper respiratory infection. The clinical presentation is classic, featuring sharp, positional and pleuritic chest pain that is relieved by sitting up and leaning forward. The associated fever and tachycardia reflect the underlying inflammatory process. The ECG findings of diffuse concave ST elevation (reflecting ventricular epicardial inflammation) and PR depression (reflecting atrial subepicardial inflammation) are pathognomonic. A pericardial friction rub is a highly specific finding on physical examination, but it is often transient and may not be present on every examination.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion, abdominal bloating, and leg swelling. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 5 years ago. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure that increases with inspiration. The lungs are clear to auscultation. He has moderate ascites and 2+ pitting edema in his lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely finding on cardiac auscultation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A pericardial friction rub is a high-pitched, scratching sound heard in acute pericarditis due to inflammation causing friction between the visceral and parietal pericardial layers. This patient's 6-month history suggests a chronic process, and in constrictive pericarditis, the pericardial layers are typically fibrosed and adherent, which does not produce a rub.

B) INCORRECT:

An opening snap is a high-pitched, early diastolic sound characteristic of mitral stenosis, caused by the forceful opening of a stenotic mitral valve. This patient's clinical picture is dominated by signs of right-sided heart failure, not the typical findings of mitral stenosis, which would include a diastolic rumble and signs of left atrial enlargement or pulmonary congestion.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of progressive right-sided heart failure (elevated JVP, ascites, and edema) with clear lungs, particularly after cardiac surgery, is classic for constrictive pericarditis. This condition involves a thickened, fibrotic pericardium that restricts diastolic ventricular filling. The pericardial knock is a high-pitched, early diastolic sound caused by the abrupt cessation of ventricular filling as the expanding ventricle hits the rigid pericardium. The increase in JVP with inspiration (Kussmaul sign) is another characteristic finding, resulting from the inability of the right ventricle to accommodate the increased venous return during inspiration.

D) INCORRECT:

An S3 gallop is a low-pitched sound in early diastole associated with rapid ventricular filling into a dilated, noncompliant ventricle, typically seen in systolic heart failure or volume overload states. Although this patient has signs of heart failure, the underlying mechanism is restrictive filling from an external constraint, not a dilated ventricle characteristic of systolic dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

An S4 gallop is a low-pitched, late diastolic sound caused by atrial contraction against a stiff, noncompliant ventricle, often due to myocardial hypertrophy from chronic hypertension or aortic stenosis. Although this represents a form of diastolic dysfunction, the specific pathophysiology in this patient is external compression by the pericardium, which produces a different characteristic sound.
questions.hint: The presence of elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) that paradoxically increases with inspiration, known as the Kussmaul sign, is a key clue to the underlying pathophysiology of impaired right ventricular filling.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity swelling. He has a history of coronary artery bypass grafting 10 years ago. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure, peripheral edema, and ascites. Lungs are clear on auscultation. An echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular systolic function and a thickened pericardium. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Brisk and bifid carotid pulse upstroke
Weak and delayed carotid pulse upstroke
Presence of a third heart sound
Paradoxical rise in jugular venous pressure with inspiration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brisk and bifid carotid pulse upstroke, known as pulsus bisferiens, is characterized by two systolic peaks and is most commonly associated with significant aortic regurgitation or hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. Neither of these conditions is supported by this patient's clinical presentation or the echocardiographic finding of a thickened pericardium.

B) INCORRECT:

Weak and delayed carotid pulse upstroke, known as pulsus parvus et tardus, is characteristic of severe aortic stenosis. It reflects the obstruction to left ventricular outflow, which is not suggested by this patient's history or echocardiogram showing normal left ventricular systolic function. This patient's symptoms are due to impaired diastolic filling, not outflow obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

A third heart sound (S3) is a low-pitched sound in early diastole caused by rapid ventricular filling into a dilated and overly compliant ventricle. It is typically associated with systolic heart failure or significant volume overload. This patient has normal systolic function and a noncompliant, constricted heart, which would not produce an S3.

D) CORRECT:

A paradoxical rise in jugular venous pressure (JVP) with inspiration describes Kussmaul sign, a typical feature of constrictive pericarditis. Normally, inspiration decreases intrathoracic pressure, increasing venous return and lowering JVP. In constrictive pericarditis, the rigid, noncompliant pericardium prevents the right ventricle from expanding to accommodate this increased venous return. Consequently, the increased blood volume backs up into the vena cava, causing a paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration. This patient's history of cardiac surgery is a significant risk factor for developing pericardial thickening and constriction. Other characteristic findings include a pericardial knock, which is an early, high-pitched diastolic sound caused by the abrupt cessation of ventricular filling.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of right-sided heart failure with preserved systolic function and a thickened pericardium, especially after cardiac surgery, is highly suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of sharp, substernal chest pain that radiates to his shoulders. He reports the pain worsens with deep inspiration and when lying down, but improves when he sits up and leans forward. He had an upper respiratory infection last week. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), his pulse is 105/min, and his blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Auscultation of the heart is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: An accentuated second heart sound in the pulmonic area
A high-pitched, scratching sound heard throughout the cardiac cycle
A mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur
A low-pitched sound in early diastole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An accentuated P2 component of the second heart sound is a sign of pulmonary hypertension. Although conditions that cause pleuritic chest pain, such as pulmonary embolism, can lead to acute pulmonary hypertension, the positional nature of this patient's pain (improving when leaning forward) is highly specific for acute pericarditis. The overall clinical presentation does not suggest chronic or significant acute pulmonary hypertension.

B) CORRECT:

A high-pitched, scratching sound describes a pericardial friction rub, the pathognomonic finding on physical examination for acute pericarditis. The rub is caused by the inflamed visceral and parietal layers of the pericardium rubbing against each other. It is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the left sternal border while the patient leans forward and holds their breath in expiration. The sound can be triphasic, corresponding to atrial systole, ventricular systole, and early ventricular diastole, but it is often biphasic or monophasic.

C) INCORRECT:

A mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur is characteristic of mitral valve prolapse. Although mitral valve prolapse can be associated with atypical chest pain, the pain is not typically pleuritic or relieved by leaning forward. This patient's recent viral illness, fever, and the specific nature of his pain make an inflammatory cause more likely than a structural valve abnormality.

D) INCORRECT:

A harsh, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur describes the murmur of aortic stenosis. Although severe aortic stenosis can cause chest pain, it is typically exertional angina due to a supply-demand mismatch. This patient's pain is pleuritic and positional, which is not characteristic of aortic stenosis. Furthermore, this condition is much more common in older adults with calcific valve disease or younger individuals with a congenital bicuspid valve.

E) INCORRECT:

A low-pitched sound in early diastole describes an S3 gallop, which is associated with increased ventricular filling pressures and is a hallmark of systolic heart failure or significant volume overload. Although this patient is tachycardic, his clinical presentation of sharp, pleuritic, and positional chest pain is not consistent with decompensated heart failure. There are no other signs of fluid overload, such as jugular venous distention or pulmonary crackles.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of sharp, pleuritic, and positional chest pain (relieved by leaning forward) after a viral upper respiratory tract infection is highly suggestive of acute pericarditis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of sharp chest pain and a nonproductive cough. The pain worsens with deep inspiration and improves when he leans forward. Three weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction and underwent stent implantation of the right coronary artery. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F) and blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation shows a high-pitched scratching sound during expiration. An x-ray of the chest shows enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and a left-sided pleural effusion. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In true ventricular aneurysms, a portion of the ventricular free wall affected by the MI will outpouch, putting patients at risk for cardiac arrhythmia, heart failure, and thrombus formation. Ventricular aneurysm occurs between 2 weeks and several months after MI, which fits the timeframe of this patient. On chest x-ray, aneurysms may cause enlargement of the cardiac silhouette. However, ventricular aneurysm would not cause the pericardial friction rub or pleuritic chest pain seen here. Furthermore, the vast majority of ventricular aneurysm form on the anterior or apical walls, due to occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery; this patient's occlusion was in the right coronary artery.

B) INCORRECT:

Stent thrombosis, which is an important consideration for any patient with recent coronary stenting, can cause a myocardial infarction and associated acute-onset chest pain and tachypnea. However, the pain of myocardial infarction is typically described as retrosternal chest discomfort, tightness, or pressure rather than the pleuritic chest pain this patient is experiencing. Furthermore, stent thrombosis would not account for this patient's pericardial friction rub or the pericardial or pleural effusions.

C) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of the pericardium with neutrophils can occur as a complication of myocardial infarction, in which case neutrophils and fibrin are found in the pericardium, adjacent to the necrotic myocardium (early infarct-associated pericarditis). Although this patient is at risk for post-MI complications, early infarct-associated pericarditis is usually seen within the first week after a myocardial infarction. This patient is 3 weeks post-MI and therefore beyond the window for early infarct-associated pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Embolism to the pulmonary artery is the mechanism of pulmonary embolism. Many of this patient's symptoms are similar to those of PE, including pleuritic chest pain, cough, and low-grade fever. This patient's left-sided pleural effusion could be explained by PE. However, chest pain that improves with leaning forward indicates a different process, and a pericardial friction rub and pericardial effusion are not features of PE.

E) CORRECT:

2–10 weeks after a myocardial infarction, an autoimmune response against cardiac antigens can lead to immune complex-mediated damage (type III hypersensitivity reaction) to the pericardium. While the exact mechanism of immune complex formation in postcardiac injury syndrome is not fully understood, the release of neoantigens from infarcted myocardium is suspected to play a role. Patients typically present with features of acute pericarditis such as fever, tachypnea, chest pain that worsens during inspiration and is alleviated by leaning forward, dry cough, pericardial friction rub, increased troponin levels, diffuse ST elevations, pericardial effusion, and pleural effusions.

F) INCORRECT:

A myocardial infarct affecting the interventricular septum can result in its rupture, creating a ventricular septal defect. This causes a left-to-right shunt, resulting in chest pain, new-onset systolic murmur, and heart failure if the defect is sufficiently large. While septal rupture can happen as late as 2 weeks post-MI, it usually happens at 3–5 days. This patient's symptoms began 3 weeks post-MI, which places him beyond the window for rupture. Furthermore, his cardiac examination revealed a pericardial friction rub, not the systolic ejection murmur that would be expected in interventricular rupture. In addition, an interventricular septal rupture would not explain this patient's pericardial effusion.
questions.hint: Fever, pleuritic chest pain, pericardial friction rub (high-pitched scratching sound), and a pericardial and unilateral pleural effusion occurring 3 weeks after an MI suggest postmyocardial infarction syndrome (Dressler syndrome).
